Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario of hypotension with no presence of bleeding and bilateral adrenalectomy is suggestive of an Addisonian crisis. It is a life-threatening condition caused due to sudden insufficiency of adrenal hormones.
Acute adrenal insufficiency (adrenal or addisonian's crisis) is a medical emergency caused due to a precipitating illness unmasking insufficiency or trauma or severe sepsis causing adrenal hemorrhage (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome) or surgical removal of the glands. It presents with non-specific symptoms such as shock with fever, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, hypocalcemia and electrolyte imbalances. It may be often misdiagnosed as an acute abdominal emergency.
Adrenal insufficiency can be primary (due to adrenal pathology), secondary (due to pituitary pathology- lack of ACTH) or tertiary (due to hypothalamus pathology- lack of CRH).
Autoimmune adrenalitis is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency worldwide. Tuberculosis is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency in India.
Adrenal crisis requires immediate intervention owing to its high mortality rate. Immediate rehydration is initiated with a saline infusion at 1 litre/hr with continuous cardiac monitoring. Glucocorticoid replacement is initiated with an initial bolus injection of hydrocortisone 100 mg followed by 200 mg over 24 hours, preferably by continuous infusion or alternatively by IV or IM injections. Mineralocorticoid replacement is initiated once the daily dose of hydrocortisone has been reduced to <50 mg, since hydrocortisone at higher doses provides sufficient stimulation of mineralocorticoids.
Solution to Question 14:
Neuroblastoma does not originate in the adrenal cortex.
Neuroblastoma is an embryonal tumour of the sympathetic nervous system. These tumours arise during fetal or early postnatal life from sympathetic cells derived from the neural crest. Therefore, tumours can originate anywhere along the path which neural crest cells migrate, including:
Adrenal medulla - most common site
Paraspinal sympathetic ganglia
Sympathetic para ganglia such as the organ of Zuckerkand
Note: Neuroblastoma is the most common abdominal (extradural) tumour in children and the most common overall tumour in infants.

Neuroblastoma arises from the adrenal medulla. Homovanillic acid (HVA) and vanillylmandelic acid(VMA) are elevated in the urine of approximately 95% of patients and are used to diagnose and monitor this tumor.
Clinical features:
Abdominal mass (retroperitoneal or hepatic)
Periorbital ecchymoses ("raccoon eyes," from periorbital ecchymosis caused by orbita metastases)
Opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome
Hypertension - due to secretion of catecholamines
Metastatic disease is present in more than 70% of patients at presentation.

Histopathology is the gold standard for diagnosis. Histologically, classic neuroblastomas are composed of small, immature ganglion cells with dark nuclei. Typically, Homer-Wright pseudorosettes can be found which are tumour cells concentrically arranged about a central space filled with neuropil.
The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumour and chemotherapy.

The image shows a markedly dilated esophagus and characteristic bird's beak appearance (distal narrowing), which is suggestive of achalasia cardia.
Achalasia cardia is caused due to the degeneration of the neurons in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus. This degeneration results in the failure of relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) on swallowing.
The patients present with a classic triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods. As the food gets accumulated in the esophagus, patients may complain of halitosis. With further progression of the disease, the patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc.
The initial diagnosis is made by barium swallow or endoscopy, which shows the presence of dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird-beak appearance). The gold standard test to confirm achalasia cardia is esophageal manometry.

Type III achalasia cardia is characterised by massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal esophagus.
Achalasia cardia occurs due to the loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus of GIT. During swallowing, the food bolus normally triggers a primary peristaltic wave, which is responsible for carrying the bolus to the stomach, accompanied by the relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to allow esophageal emptying into the stomach.
Achalasia is characterized by a disruption of this normal process. Failure of relaxation of the LES causes an elevated median integrated relaxation pressure and a complete failure of peristalsis. The esophagus becomes progressively more tortuous, leading to a megaesophagus.

The patient likely has achalasia cardia and the definitive treatment is Heller's myotomy. Surgical management is the first-line treatment modality.
Achalasia or 'failure to relax' in Greek occurs due to the lack of ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus (Auerbach's). The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) fails to relax leading to dysphagia, regurgitation of food, and progressive dilation of the esophagus proximal to the constriction.
Barium radiology shows hold-up in the distal esophagus, abnormal contractions in the oesophageal body, and a tapering stricture in the distal esophagus often described as a ‘bird’s beak’.

Diffuse esophageal spasm is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus. It is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the esophageal body. It is more common in women.

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a hiatus hernia. Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any abdominal structure other than the esophagus into the thoracic cavity through a widening of the hiatus of the diaphragm.
Type 1 - sliding hernia:
Gastroesophageal junction or cardia migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of intra abdominal esophagus is reduced leading to GERD. Most of the patients are asymptomatic. The treatment of choice in symptomatic patients is fundoplication.
Type 2 - rolling hiatus hernia:
Gastroesophageal junction or cardia is normal but a portion of the stomach migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of intra abdominal esophagus remains the same in a true rolling hiatus hernia.

Chest pain or fullness relieved on belching.
Dysphagia.
Longitudinal ulcers (Cameron’s ulcer) that bleeds, leading to anemia.
Surgical reduction of hernia and tightening of diaphragmatic crura is the best treatment modality even in asymptomatic patients to avoid life-threatening complications like volvulus.
Type 3 - mixed hiatus hernia:
A combination of sliding and rolling hiatus hernia. Treatment is the same as rolling hiatus hernia. Type 4 hiatus hernia:
Other contents of GIT herniates into the thoracic cavity. Eg: Colon.

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2-8 weeks of age.
When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality i.e hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development
of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-). The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, the loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone via the RAAS pathway. The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions. Loss of potassium ions leads to the development
of hypokalemia. Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is
called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead of
compensating that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine. The cervix sign and nipple sign are signs of CHPS seen on ultrasonography:
Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called nipple ign.
The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is sometimes referred to as the cervix sign.

It is characterized by multiple superficial (non-ulcerating) erosions that begin in the proximal or acid-secreting portion of the stomach and progress distally. They are almost always seen in the fundus of the stomach and usually develop within 1 to 2 days after a traumatic event.
The stress-induced splanchnic vasoconstriction causes systemic hypotension and reduced blood flow leading to mucosal injury.
On microscopic examination, they appear as wedge-shaped mucosal hemorrhages, with coagulation necrosis of the superficial mucosal cells. Stress ulcers present as painless upper GI bleeds.
Note: Cushing ulcers arise in individuals with intracranial disease. They occur in the stomach, duodenum, and esophagus and carry a high incidence of perforation. They occur due to gastric acid hypersecretion from direct vagal nerve stimulation.

The clinical scenario is suggestive of early dumping syndrome. Hypoglycemia■ does not occur in early dumping syndrome. Hypoglycemia is seen in late dumping syndrome secondary to raised insulin levels.
Dumping syndrome is a complication occurring post gastrectomy. It can be early or late.
Early dumping syndrome is due to the high osmotic load that reaches the small bowel, leading to sequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract (GIT). This fluid shift induces autonomic responses. It is characterized by more GI and fewer cardiovascular effects such as:
Epigastric fullne
Sweating
Lightheadedne
Tachycardia
Diarrhea
Symptoms are aggravated by having more food and relieved by lying down.
Late dumping syndrome is due to an increase in insulin levels and secondary hypoglycemia. This hypoglycemia causes a catecholamine surge, which results in predominantly cardiovascular effects such as:
Diaphoresi
Tremulousne
Light-headedne
Tachycardia
Confusion
The symptoms are aggravated by exercise and relieved by having food.
The principal treatment for both types of dumping syndrome is dietary manipulation. Meals based on fat and protein are known to work the best. Octreotide before meals is useful.

The given clinical scenario and the image showing the presence of hypertrophied gastric mucosal folds are characteristic of Menetrier’s disease. Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases of Menetrier's disease.
Menetrier's disease is a premalignant condition. The disease seems to be caused by overexpression of transforming growth factor-alpha i.e., TGF-alpha (not TNF-alpha), which stimulates the EGFR pathway, resulting in increased proliferation of mucus cells/foveolar hyperplasia. This results in gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, mucus production, and hypochlorhydria. The antrum is usually spared.
There is a loss of albumin (up to 10 g/day), across the gastric mucosa leading to hypoproteinemia. Secondary symptoms include weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema.
Histologically, it is characterized by hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance as shown in the image below.

Cetuximab, an EGFR inhibitory antibody, is now considered the first-line treatment for Menetrier's disease, leaving total gastrectomy for severe disease with persistent and substantial protein loss refractory to cetuximab.

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of intestinal obstruction, due to a strangulated inguinal hernia. The ideal management is exploratory laparotomy as soon as possible with ongoing resuscitative measures until surgery.
Bowel strangulation is a type of mechanical bowel obstruction, associated with complete cessation of blood supply leading to irreversible loss of viability of the affected bowel segment. Inguinal hernias, most commonly of non-reducible type, are associated with a high chance of strangulation and need urgent medical intervention.
Bowel strangulation can be suspected in the presence of
constant severe abdominal pain,
abdominal tenderness with rigidity and peritonism,
signs of shock, and lack of response to conservative management.
Reduced bowel wall enhancement on CT
When strangulation occurs in an external hernia, the lump is tense, tender, and irreducible with overlying skin changes (erythema or purplish discoloration).

IV fluids
Nasogastric tube to decompress the bowel and reduce abdominal distention
IV antibiotics (adequate coverage required for gram -ve and anaerobes)
Analgesia
Definitive management:
Continue supportive management up to 72 hrs if suspicious of adhesions. Surgical exploration and adhesiolysis should be done if there is no improvement.
Immediate surgical exploration and resection of non-viable gut segments if suspicious of any of the following:
Obstructed external hernia
Clinical features suspicious of intestinal strangulation
Obstruction in a ‘virgin’ abdomen (i.e no prior history of intraabdominal surgery)

Meckel’s diverticulum is the most commonly encountered congenital anomaly of the small intestine. Meckel’s diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct or omphalomesenteric duct that develops during weeks 5 to 7 of gestation. It contains all 3 layers of the intestine and hence it is a true diverticulum.
It is located 45 to 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve. The most common heterotopic tissue within the Meckel’s diverticulum is gastric mucosa (50%) followed by pancreatic mucosa(5%) and colonic mucosa.
Most Meckel’s diverticula are benign and are incidentally discovered. Its clinical features include:

Volvulus
Intussusception (ileo-ileal or ileo-colic)
Incarcerated Littre’s hernia. Complications of Meckel's diverticulum are:
Diverticulitis - presents like appendicitis
Perforation - resembles a perforated duodenal ulcer
Peritonitis
Neoplasms - neuroendocrine tumour (most common) > adenocarcinoma > GIST >

Absence of bowel sounds
Absolute constipation

No passage of flatus

Paralytic ileus is managed by nasogastric tube decompression and restriction of oral intake until bowel sounds and the passage of flatus return. Electrolyte balance must be maintained.

Enteroclysis is the investigation of choice in patients with small bowel tumours.
Enteroclysis is a barium study in which the contrast agent is put directly into the duodenum through a nasogastric tube.
Continued infusion of 500 to 1000 mL of thin barium sulfate and methylcellulose suspension is done and then viewed continuously with the use of either fluoroscopy or radiographs taken at frequent intervals. Enteroclysis has a sensitivity of over 90% in the detection of small bowel tumours and is the investigation of choice, particularly for tumours located in the distal small bowel.

The contrast is administered at a controlled rate directly in the small bowel, bypassing the regulatory action of the pylorus.

Small sinus tracts and fistulas

Skip lesions
Proximal and distal extent of diffuse diseases.
The examination can be completed in 15–30 minutes, thus reducing patient waiting time.

Solution to Question 1:
Aphthous ulcers, surrounded by a rim of erythematous mucosa, are the earliest lesions seen in a patient with Crohn's disease during endoscopy.
Crohn's colitis usually spares the rectum and is most severe in the ileocaecal region.
In early Crohn's disease, small, punched-out aphthous ulcers are often seen (the result of submucosal lymphoid follicle expansion).
In moderate disease, the aphthous ulcers coalesce into larger ulcers, which may take on the appearance of a star (stellate ulcers).
As disease severity increases, submucosal edema and injury can result in cobblestoning of the mucosa (option A) and eventually the formation of serpiginous ulcers, which are typical findings in Crohn's disease.
Thorn-like extraluminal projections in barium studies are known as rose-thorn appearance, and are a typical sign of Crohn's disease. They represent deep penetrating linear ulcers or fissurings typically seen within stenosed terminal ileum with a thickened wall. (Options C and D)

Symptomatic relapse of Crohn's disease after surgery is not related to the presence of the disease during resection.
The course of the disease after surgery is unpredictable since surgery does not cure Crohn's disease. Instead, the probability of relapse increases with the time since resection.
Other options:

Option C: The terminal ileum is most commonly involved in Crohn's disease.

The clinical scenario and the radiograph are suggestive of toxic megacolon.
Toxic megacolon may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension. Abdominal radiography shows transverse or right colonic dilation of >6 cm and loss of haustrations. It is usually associated with ulcerative colitis as indicated by history of chronic bloody diarrhoea.
It can be triggered by electrolyte imbalance and narcotics which interfere with gut motility. Features of secondary bacterial infecton and sepsis may be present. It can be complicated by intestinal perforation.
It usually resolves with supportive treatment (correcting electrolyte imbalance, fluids, and bowel rest) and medical therapy which includes glucocorticoids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and antibiotics. However, an urgent colectomy is indicated in patients who do not show signs of improvement.
Indications for urgent surgery include:
Frank intraperitoneal peritonitis, secondary to perforation
Life-threatening hemorrhage or increasing transfusion requirements
Worsening systemic toxicity
Worsening colonic dilatation Other options:
Option B: Volvulus occurs when the air-filled segment of the colon twists around the mesentery. The sigmoid colon is the most commonly involved part of the large intestine (90%). The patient can present with abdominal distension, nausea and vomiting. X-ray abdomen shows a bent inner tube or coffee bean appearance.

Option C: Ogilvie syndrome, also known as colonic pseudo-obstruction is a functional disorder with colonic dilatation without mechanical obstruction. It occurs commonly in hospitalized patients and is associated with narcotics, bed rest and comorbid disease. X-ray shows dilatation of the colon (predominantly transverse colon) with absent mechanical obstruction.

Option D: Pneumatosis intestinalis is the presence of gas within the bowel wall seen in any part of the GI tract but most commonly in the jejunum. It is a pathognomic feature of necrotizing enterocolitis. X-ray of the abdomen will show intramural gas in the bowel.

Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray film showing saw-toothed appearance of the colon are suggestive of colonic diverticulosis. They are false diverticula.
Diverticulosis refers to the herniation of the mucosa and muscularis mucosa through the colonic wall, usually at the point where the nutrient artery enters the colon (mesenteric side). The condition is usually asymptomatic until complications arise. They may be detected incidentally. On a barium X-ray, the colon with diverticular disease will have a saw-toothed appearance.
Colonic diverticula are more often acquired than congenital. They are common in developed countries that have a low fiber diet. A low fiber diet results in low stool volume. As the colon generates higher intraluminal pressure to propel smaller volumes of stools, low stool volumes cause an increase in colonic wall tension and segmentation of the colon.

Ischemic colitis occurs due to interruption or decrease in colonic blood flow. It may occur with many different conditions, including embolism from cardiac disease, low-flow states such as congestive heart failure, sepsis, and vasopressor use. Solution to Question 15:
The structures cut when the initial incision gridiron incision (McBurney's incision) is converted to the Rutherford Morrison incision are the external oblique, internal oblique, and transverse abdominis muscles.
When the preoperative diagnosis is reasonably certain, the widely used incision for appendectomy is known as the gridiron incision. It is made perpendicular to a line connecting the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus, with its center at McBurney's point. When better access is needed, the gridiron incision can be converted to a Rutherford Morison incision by extending the incision obliquely upwards and laterally.
Rutherford Morison's incision is suitable for a para- or retrocecal appendix that is fixed. It is an oblique muscle-cutting incision starting from McBurney's point and extending upward and laterally as needed. All layers (skin, subcutaneous tissues, external oblique, internal
oblique, transversus abdominis, and the peritoneum) are divided along the incision line.
In recent years, the transverse skin crease (Lanz) incision has gained popularity due to improved exposure and ease of extension when necessary. This incision is placed approximately 2 cm below the umbilicus along the midclavicular-midinguinal line, with its length adjusted according to the patient's size and obesity. If required, the incision can be extended medially by retracting or dividing the rectus abdominis muscle (statement 4).
When there is uncertainty in the diagnosis, especially in the presence of intestinal obstruction, a lower midline abdominal incision is preferred over a right lower paramedian incision.

On gross examination, it is a moderately hard, yellow tumour between the intact mucosa and the peritoneum. Microscopically, tumour cells are small, arranged in small nests within the muscle, and have a characteristic pattern using immunohistochemical stain for chromogranin B.

Pseudomyxoma peritonei refers to a condition of mucinous ascites arising due to the rupture of a mucinous tumor of appendix or ovary. It most commonly occurs in patients between 40-50 years of age. They are often asymptomatic or present with non-specific complaints like abdominal pain and distension.
Physical examination may reveal ascites with non shifting dullness and rarely, a palpable abdominal mass. CT scan may reveal accumulation of mucinous material and scalloped indentation of the visceral surfaces of the liver and spleen. The peritoneal surfaces may be thickened due to the solid components of the tumor. The histology of the primary appendiceal tumor is an important predictor of survival.
Management consists of extensive resection of the tumor (cytoreduction) and intraperitoneal heated chemotherapy (IPHC). Surgical management may include omentectomy, resection of the peritoneum and involved organs, appendectomy or a right hemicolectomy.

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is autosomal dominant. It is characterized by the presence of >100 adenomatous polyps in colon and rectum. It usually manifests by the late 2nd or early 3rd decade. Although it accounts for 1% of all colorectal carcinoma, the risk of development of cancer is 100%.

Solution to Question 9:
The most common presentation of an abdominal desmoid tumor is an abdominal mass.
Desmoid tumors, also known as fibromatosis, aggressive fibromatosis or desmoid-type fibromatosis are locally aggressive tumors that lack metastatic potential. Desmoid tumors can be sporadic in origin or associated with familial adenomatous polyposis.
These tumors arise from fibro-aponeurotic tissue and typically are manifested as a slowly growing mass. They present as firm, non-painful, non-tender masses in the abdominal wall, shoulder, hip and limbs, mesentery, and pelvis. They are also associated with trauma, pregnancy, and oral contraceptive usage.
The investigation of choice for a desmoid tumor is MRI. It is superior to CT in defining the pattern and the extent of involvement and can determine recurrence after surgery. Diagnosis is established by a biopsy with immunohistochemistry, which stains positive for beta-catenin, actin and vimentin, and negative for desmin, cytokeratin and S-100.
Treatment:
An initial observation is preferred for stable, asymptomatic, primary or recurrent desmoids, especially if surgery can cause high mortality.
Surgical resection with negative margin clearance is reserved for patients with small abdomina wall tumors associated with pain or an increase in size.
Tamoxifen and NSAIDs are used as first-line medical therapy. Other systemic treatment options are low-dose chemotherapy, tyrosinase kinase inhibitors, and full-dose chemotherapy
Radiotherapy is preferred for candidates unfit for surgery, patients refusing surgery and when surgical resection is associated with high morbidity.

In Hartmann's procedure, the segment of the colon containing the obstructing cancer is resected and closure of the distal sigmoid or rectum is performed. A colostomy is made. Later, intestinal continuity is re-established by the closure of the colostomy and fashioning a colorectal anastomosis.
This procedure is preferred in patients when a resection and primary anastomosis cannot be performed immediately due to complications such as inflammation of the bowel, perforation, or peritonitis.
Resection and primary anastomosis is done in patients who are hemodynamically stable and have pliable, nonedematous, well-vascularized bowel.
In this procedure, the segment of the left colon containing the cancer is resected. The remaining colon is cleaned with saline lavage by inserting a catheter through the appendix or ileum into the cecum and irrigating the contents from the colon. Primary anastomosis between the prepared colon and rectum is fashioned subsequently, without the need for a temporary colostomy
Stent placement via colonoscope is a temporary measure to obtain time for bowel preparation for primary anastomosis. A stent that traverses the tumor is placed to relieve the obstruction. It is done in partial obstruction and is preferred in old and frail patients.

The puborectalis muscle encircles the posterior and lateral aspects of the anorectal junction, creating the anorectal angle.
At rest, the anorectal angle is held at 90 - 100°. This becomes more acute (70 - 90°) during squeezing due to the contraction and shortening of the puborectalis muscle. This brings the
anorectal junction higher and nearer to the pubic symphysis.
During straining and defecation, the anorectal angle becomes more obtuse (110 - 180°) due to relaxation of the puborectalis muscle.
The anorectal ring is formed by the fusion of:
Puborectalis
Deep external anal sphincter
Internal anal sphincter
Note: Anismus, is caused by a failure of the puborectalis and external anal sphincter to relax during defecation straining. This results in a failure of the anorectal angle to straighten during defecation.

Solution to Question 3:
Waldeyer's fascia separates the rectum from the coccyx. The lower third of the rectum is separated by the following:
from the prostate or vagina anteriorly - by Denonvilliers’ fascia

Waldeyer's fascia originates at the S2 to S4 level from the presacral parietal fascia and fuses with the rectal visceral fascia at the posterior aspect of the rectum. It divides the retrorectal space into
superior and inferior compartments.
Identification and preservation of the presacral fascia play an important role in preventing complications and reducing local recurrences of rectal cancer.

Historically, a 5 cm clearance margin was the common practice. However, the 5 cm rule has been replaced by the 2 cm rule to help preserve the anal sphincters.
When a negative distal margin can be achieved by sparing the sphincter, a sphincter sparing surgery such as low anterior resection (LAR) is performed.
If it is not possible to achieve a negative distal margin and spare the sphincter (when the tumour is within 5cm of anal verge), abdominal perineal resection (APR) is done.
APR/LAR must include total mesorectal excision (TME) to ensure margin clearance and lymph node retrieval.

In patients who cannot tolerate low anastomosis.

Solution to Question 10:
Over 90% of fissures are located in the posterior midline, with the rest being located in the anterior midline of the anal canal.
The main hypothesis is that the posterior midline area may have decreased blood flow due to the configuration of the blood vessels of the anus. Also, the spasm of the internal anal sphincter may cause further reduction of the blood flow to the posterior anal canal.

Surgical therapy has traditionally been recommended for chronic anal fissures that have failed medical therapy. The aim of this procedure is to decrease the spasms of the internal sphincter by dividing a portion of the muscle. Approximately 30% of the muscle sphincter fibers are divided laterally using an open or closed technique.

A fistula-in-ano is an epithelial-lined tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin. Patients usually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and pain. Anal fistulas can be simplex or complex fistulas.
Simple fistulas- include a single tract, subcutaneous tract, and those that involve less than 30% of the external sphincter. They are easier to treat, and have lower chances of recurrence.
Complex fistulas- include fistulas involving more than 30% of the external sphincter, with multiple tracts, recurrent fistulas, and those associated with other predisposing factors, such as Crohn disease and radiation treatment.
Fistulas can also be classified into high or low-lying fistulas, based on their location with respect to the puborectalis muscle.

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin.
Goodsall’s rule:
Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radia tract.
Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.
However, exceptions to this rule often occur. Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline

In the given scenario, a history of Crohn's disease, recurrent anorectal abscess, and the imaging findings point towards a complex anal fistula. It will be managed using Seton's placement, which is done in two stages.
A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis. Setons can be classified as draining or cutting.

Cutting seton
A cutting seton has been used as a staged fistulectomy, especially in high trans-sphincteric fistulas. After the seton is passed during the primary surgery, it has to be tightened at regular intervals, till it cuts through completely.
Loose/draining seton
In this method, the seton is placed to maintain drainage and create scar tissue around the sphincter so that its edges do not retract after cutting.

Pilonidal sinus disease is a disease of the inter-gluteal region, characterized by the formation of a sinus in the cleft of the buttocks. It is more common in males between 15-40 years of age.
Risk factors include:
Male sex
Family history
Being overweight or obese
Trauma or irritation to the perianal region

Hirsute habitus - thick body hair
Poor hygiene Sites involved:

Face

Buttock friction and shearing forces in these areas allow broken hairs to enter the skin and create a subcutaneous, chronically infected midline track. An infected hair follicle can also form such a track. Secondary tracks can arise as openings, lined with granulation tissue and discharge.

Intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine
Abscess - due to a foreign-body-type reaction Treatment
Conservative treatment: Strict hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area.
Abscess:
Rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
If refractory to the above treatment- drainage with thorough curettage of granulation tissue and hair.

The given history and presence of large vacuolated cells (Paget cells) on biopsy is suggestive of Paget's disease of the anal canal. It is a rare intraepithelial adenocarcinoma.
Paget’s disease is most commonly seen in areas with a high density of apocrine sweat glands, in elderly females. These can develop into an invasive cancer of the underlying apocrine glands.
Clinical features include intractable itching, burning, bleeding per rectally. 10% of the patients are asymptomatic. On examination, eczematous, well-demarcated plaque, with occasional ulceration and scaling can be seen.

Treatment of choice- complete excision
Limited, noninvasive disease-wide local excision and closure of the defect with primary sutures or with V-Y advancement flaps
Invasive component- radical resection with abdominoperineal resection (APR)
Medically unfit for surgery - topical 5-FU, imiquimod, cryotherapy, or argon beam laser therapy
Recurrence- re-excision (as long as the disease remains noninvasive)
Note: Most common site of extra-mammary Paget’s disease – anogenital region > axilla > eyelid. Perianal Paget’s disease is usually associated with underlying visceral malignancy, most commonly colorectal adenocarcinoma.

Solution to Question 6:
Indirect inguinal hernias are by far the most common type of hernia in women. It is the most common hernia regardless of gender.
In men, indirect hernias predominate over direct hernias at a ratio of 2:1. Femoral hernia and umbilical hernias are more common in females compared to males at ratios of 10:1 and 2:1, respectively. Although femoral hernias occur more frequently in women than in men, inguinal hernia remains the most common hernia in women.
Solution to Question 7:

Femoral hernia is below and lateral to the pubic tubercle.
Another structure that is useful in differentiating between inguinal and femoral hernia is inguinal ligament. An inguinal hernia leaves the abdominal cavity just above the inguinal ligament and a femoral hernia leaves just below the inguinal ligament.

Solution to Question 10:
Strangulation is the most common serious complication of a hernia.
An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in the sac of a hernia.An incarcerated hernia can lead to a bowel obstruction or
strangulation. Obstruction is characterized by colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, abdominal distension and obstipation. Features of obstruction along with vascular compromise is seen in strangluation. Strangulation occurs in 1% to 3% of groin hernias. It is more common at the extremes of life.
Most strangulated hernias are indirect inguinal hernias. However, femoral hernias have the highest rate of strangulation (15% to 20%) of all hernias, and it is, therefore, recommended that all femoral hernias be repaired at the time of discovery. Tenderness is the first sign of strangulation.
The first step is the correction of hypovolemia. The treatment of choice is immediate surgery. The fundus is opened first during surgery.
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of a direct hernia, for which Lichtenstein mesh repair is the appropriate surgical method for its management.
The contents of a direct hernia protrude outward, forward, and medial to the inferior epigastric artery and the deep inguinal ring. Whereas, the contents of an indirect hernia protrude lateral to the inferior epigastric artery. The sac of an indirect inguinal hernia passes from the deep inguinal ring obliquely towards the superficial inguinal ring and then to the scrotum.
A direct hernia protrudes through the Hesselbach triangle, which is a zone of weakness for direct hernias.
A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating an inguinal hernia. It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anterior tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic nonabsorbable mesh is used to bridge the defect in this repair.

Other surgical methods used for the repair of an inguinal hernia are:
Bassini repair - It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. In this method, a mesh is not used. It is associated with a high recurrence and is not used frequently now. It is used only in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis where the use of a mesh is not preferred. It is performed by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches/conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament.
Shouldice repair - It is a multilayered repair, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is strengthened by continuous sutures. It involves double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It is associated with a very low recurrence rate.
Gilbert repair (plug and patch repair) - It is an extension of Lichtenstein’s original mesh repair and has now become the most commonly performed primary anterior inguinal hernia repair. In this technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used. It is deployed like an
upside-down umbrella when inserted into the internal inguinal ring to occlude the hernia
McVay repair (Cooper's ligament repair) is used for the correction of direct inguinal hernia, large indirect hernia, recurrent hernia, femoral hernias (particularly suited for strangulated femora
hernias). In this method, the transversus abdominis aponeurosis is approximated to Cooper's ligament.
Stoppa-Rives repair - It is used for the repair of large, recurrent, or bilateral hernias. In this method, a sub-umbilical midline incision is given to place a large mesh into the preperitonea space.
Herniotomy - It is used to treat inguinal hernia in a child which occurs due to the presence of
a patent processus vaginalis. Therefore in herniotomy, the repair of the inguinal ring is not done.
Solution to Question 12:
With smaller defects, the mesh does not need to be sutured in Stoppa's repair.
This is based on Pascal's law. Pascal’s law states that any additional pressure exerted on an enclosed fluid mass is transmitted equally in all directions.The abdomen is an enclosed space and intra-abdominal pressure is distributed equally over the mesh, thereby keeping the mesh in place.
Stoppa's repair is an open preperitoneal mesh repair primarily indicated for large, recurrent, bilateral hernias.
In Stoppa’s mesh repair, a large piece of mesh is placed in the retro muscular space, over the posterior rectus sheath or peritoneum. This mesh is not sutured in patients with small defects because it is held in place by intra-abdominal pressure (Pascal’s law). This allows the eventual incorporation of the mesh with the surrounding tissues. Alternatively, in larger defects, the mesh can be secured laterally with several sutures.

This is because the inguinal hernia in the pediatric population is due to the presence of patent processus vaginalis and not due to the weakening of the abdominal muscles or the ligaments.
Herniotomy involves either reduction of the hernial sac alone, or opening of the hernial sac, reduction of the contents, transfixation of the neck, and excision of the patent processus vaginalis/ hernial sac.
Solution to Question 14:
The most appropriate mesh used in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores.
Lightweight meshes generally contain less material and induce a less-pronounced foreign body reaction and decreased inflammatory response, which results in better tissue incorporation, increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.
Meshes with large pores exhibit less inflammatory infiltrate, connective tissue, and scar bridging, which allows increased soft tissue ingrowth. They have greater elasticity and flexibility and also shrink less resulting in lesser adhesions, better tissue incorporation, and decreased patient discomfort and pain. So the best mesh type among the given options is lightweight mesh with large pores.
Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological depending on their composition. Synthetic meshes are made from polypropylene, polyester, or PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene). PTFE meshes are hydrophobic with a lower risk of adhesion.
Biological meshes are acellular matrix materials derived from humans or animals and have lesser complications. But due to poor collagen deposition and absorption, they rapidly lose mechanical strength and hence their use is restricted to infected environments.
Note: To promote better tissue integration, a composite mesh was developed which combines the attributes of polypropylene and PTFE by layering the two substances on top of one another.

Hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) is the pressure gradient between the portal vein and the inferior vena cava (IVC). It is a measure of portal venous pressure. It can quantify the degree of portal hypertension due to sinusoidal resistance to blood flow.

Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Its life cycle consists of sheep and dogs as hosts. Humans are accidental hosts.
A hydatid cyst usually develops three weeks after the infection. The cyst is surrounded by a fibrous capsule called pericyst that is derived from the host tissue.
The cyst wall is composed of two layers, ectocyst (outer gelatinous membrane), and endocyst (inner germinal membrane). Ectocyst is a laminated membrane, which is acellular. It helps in the passage of nutrients. The endocyst helps in producing the laminated membrane and scoleces.
The brood capsules are cellular masses in the hydatid fluid which consists of scoleces. In a definitive host, these scoleces develop into adult tapeworm while in the intermediate hosts these develop into new hydatid cysts. The brood capsules are attached to the endocyst by a pedicle or stalk.
The brood capsules may mature and detach from the mother cyst and become the daughter cysts, which are an exact replica of the mother cysts. The freed brood capsules and scoleces present in the hydatid fluid are called hydatid sand.

The clinical presentation of a hydatid cyst is largely asymptomatic, until complications occur. The most common presenting symptoms are abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and vomiting. The most frequent sign is hepatomegaly.

The given CECT abdomen shows a well-defined hypodense lesion in the liver with asymmetrical nodular peripheral enhancement which is characteristic of hemangioma.
Hemangioma is a benign tumor composed of increased proliferation of blood vessels. It is the most common benign tumour of the liver and is mainly seen in women at a mean age of 45 years.
Small capillary hemangiomas are of no clinical significance. They are usually solitary, <5 cm in diameter, with equal occurrence in the right and left halves of the liver. However, giant hemangiomas of diameter >5 cm require attention.
They are most commonly asymptomatic and incidentally found during imaging studies. Large compressive masses may cause vague upper abdominal symptoms. The appearance of hepatic hemangioma in a contrast-enhanced CT scan is as follows:
Non-contrast phase: Well-defined hypodense lesion
Arterial phase: Peripheral nodular enhancement
Washout phase: Homogenous enhancement

Solution to Question 11:
The patient should ideally be treated by preoperative portal vein embolization to improve hepatic functional reserve, followed by resection which will decrease the tumor burden.
Portal venous embolization on the side of the tumor will lead to compensatory hypertrophy of the unaffected liver lobe. This improves the volume and function of the future liver remnant (FLR).
Localized hepatocellular carcinoma
Child-Pugh class A: Patients with child-pugh class A should undergo resection of the tumor.
Those with low FLR (<30%) should ideally be treated by preoperative portal vein embolization followed by resection. Preoperative embolization helps in improving the FLR volume function prior to resection.
Those with adequate FLR (>30-40%) can usually tolerate resection alone.
Child-Pugh class B/C or portal hypertension: Patients with early-stage HCC and child-Pugh class B/C or portal hypertension should be considered for transplantation.
Advanced hepatocellular carcinoma
Patients with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma are treated with palliative intent. Following are the management options:
Drug therapy - Sorafenib/ Sunitinib/ Regorafenib
Transarterial chemoembolisation (TACE) and transarterial radioembolisation (TARE) offer the best results in multifocal disease
Radiofrequency ablation, microwave ablation, high-frequency ultrasound therapy are alternative options
Patients with extreme deterioration of performance status and liver function should be offered supportive treatment only.

Solution to Question 1:
The gallbladder does not have muscularis mucosa and submucosa. Those layers are absent in the gallbladder.
The mucosa of the cystic duct is arranged in spiral folds known as the valves of the Heister. The valves act to keep gallstones from entering the common bile duct in spite of distention and intraluminal pressure.
Hartmann’s pouch is a diverticulum that can occur at the neck of the gallbladder. It may obscure the cystic duct and Calot’s triangle during laparascopic surgical dissection.
The Phrygian cap is present in 2–6 percent of cholecystograms and may be mistaken for a pathological deformity of the organ. It is not an indication for cholecystectomy.

Solution to Question 2:
The inferior surface of the liver forms the boundary of the hepatobiliary triangle, not Calot’s triangle.
Calot's triangle is an important surgical landmark as the cystic artery usually can be found within its boundaries. The cystic artery should be identified while performing a cholecystectomy to avoid damage to the extrahepatic biliary system.
Occasionally, there can be a tortuous course of the right hepatic artery in some patients. This is called Moynihan's hump or caterpillar hump. It is an important anomaly that should be recognized in order to prevent intraoperative vascular and biliary injuries.

Note: The cystic artery is one of the contents as well as forms the superior boundary of the Calot's triangle (originally described in 1891 by Jean-François Calot)
Solution to Question 3:
The most common type of gallstone to be seen in the asian population is pigment stone (80%).
The most common type of gallstone worldwide is mixed stone. Three main types of gallstones include:
Cholesterol stones - They consist of cholesterol monohydrate crystals. Pure cholesterol stones are uncommon and account for <10% of all cases.
Pigment stones (brown or black) contain <30% cholesterol:
Black stones - Made up of insoluble bilirubin pigment polymer mixed with calcium phosphate and calcium bicarbonate. They are associated with hemolysis, usually seen in hereditary spherocytosis or sickle cell disease.
Brown stones - Contain calcium bilirubinate, calcium palmitate, and calcium stearate, as well as cholesterol. They are also associated with the presence of foreign bodies within the bile ducts, such as endoprostheses (stents), or parasites, such as Clonorchis sinensis and Ascaris umbricoides.
Mixed stones.

Only 10% of gallstones are radiopaque.
Approximately 90% of renal stones, 10% of gall stones, and 5% of appendicoliths contain enough calcium to appear radiopaque on plain films.
Gallbladder diseases are regularly diagnosed by ultrasound because of the superficial location of the gallbladder and the absence of overlying bowel gas. Ultrasound has a high specificity and sensitivity for cholelithiasis. It is considered as the first test of choice for delineation of any biliary pathology. Stones appear acoustically dense and also produce an acoustic shadow. They also move with a change in posture. However, CT provides superior anatomic information and therefore is indicated when more anatomic delineation is required.

Solution to Question 7:
Non-visualization of the gallbladder in HIDA (hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid) scan is suggestive of acute cholecystitis.
Acute cholecystitis is the inflammation of the gallbladder that develops over hours, usually because a gallstone obstructs the cystic duct. In the majority of cases, the process is limited by the stone slipping back into the body of the gallbladder. Clinical features include:
Pain in the right hypochondrium with referred pain to the back
Fever
Nausea, vomiting, dyspepsia
Jaundice
Positive Murphy's sign
Positive Boas' sign
Murphy's sign: After asking the patient to exhale, the examiner places his hand below the costal margin on the right side at the mid-clavicular line of the patient. The patient is then instructed to take a deep inspiration. If the patient stops breathing and winces with a ‘catch’ of breath, Murphy’s sign is said to be positive.
Boas' sign: It is the presence of an area of hyperaesthesia at the site of radiation of the pain to the back, typically, below the scapula.
USG and CT scans are helpful in establishing a diagnosis. The gold standard investigation of acute cholecystitis is the HIDA scan. The radioisotope used is Technetium-99m ( 99mTc)-labeled derivative of iminodiacetic acid.
The following image depicts the radioisotope scan in which the gallbladder is not visualized even after 4 hours.

Unlike bilirubin, iminodiacetic acid (IDA) compounds do not undergo conjugation in the hepatocytes. They are rapidly excreted into the bile. This enables excellent visualization of the bile ducts and gallbladder within 30–60 minutes of injection.
Since cystic duct obstruction initiates acute cholecystitis, there is non-visualization of the gallbladder 3 - 4 hours after the intravenous injection of 99m Tc-IDA. This is characteristic of acute cholecystitis. Thus visualization of the GB establishes cystic duct patency and rules out acute cholecystitis.

Acute and chronic inflammation of the gallbladder can occur in the absence of stones and are referred to as acalculous cholecystitis.
It is mainly seen in critically ill patients and those recovering from major surgery, trauma, and burns. It has a high mortality rate.

It is usually asymptomatic, although chronic right upper quadrant pain may also occur. On examination, a visible, easily palpable, non-tender gallbladder, sometimes extending from the right upper quadrant into the right iliac fossa may be seen.

The given clinical scenario with an X-ray showing gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia) and multiple air-fluid levels indicating small bowel obstruction is suggestive of gallstone ileus. The distal ileum is the most common site to be obstructed in gallstone ileus because it tapers before entering the cecum.
Gallstone ileus is caused by the obstruction of the intestinal lumen by a gallstone, leading to a mechanical blockage. Big gallstones will not be able to pass through the normal cystic duct. This causes inflammation of the gallbladder and results in pressure necrosis. This in turn leads to biliary-enteric fistula formation.
Plain radiographs demonstrate air-fluid levels consistent with a small bowel obstruction. Rigler's triad is seen in gallstone ileus. It includes:
Intestinal obstruction
Gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia)
Ectopic gallstone (Radio-opaque shadow in the right iliac fossa)
The investigation of choice is the CT scan. Pneumobilia is a ubiquitous finding because the fistula that permitted a stone to pass into the duodenum allows air into the gallbladder and the biliary tree.
Initial management involves keeping the patient nil per-oral, IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and analgesics.
If there is no strangulation or peritonitis, it can be managed by:
Milking the stone beyond ileocaecal junction
Crushing the stone
Enterotomy to remove the stone
If there is perforation or strangulation, resection and anastomosis are done.
Cholecystectomy should be performed to avoid future complications. Fistula closure can be performed along with cholecystectomy or it can be performed later (two-stage procedure).

According to Courvoisier's law, the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mild jaundice, is unlikely due to gallstones. It usually indicates a possibility of carcinoma in the head of the pancreas. However, apart from a cancer in the pancreatic head, certain other conditions may also cause a palpable gallbladder in presence of jaundice. For example,
Double impacted stones (stones in both the cystic duct and the distal common bile duct)
Primary CBD stone
Oriental cholangiohepatitis
Mirizzi's syndrome (an impacted gallstone in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder due to inflammation, causing common bile duct (CBD) obstruction, jaundice and a palpable gallbladder)
These are considered exceptions to Courvoisier's law.
Solution to Question 20:
The given scenario is suggestive of choledocholithiasis. When diagnosed postoperatively (after cholecystectomy), it should be managed with ERCP + sphincterotomy.
Stone detected within 2 years after cholecystectomy is called retained stone. Stone detected more than 2 years after cholecystectomy is considered recurrent stone.
CBD stone and GB stone detected before cholecystectomy:
ERCP+Sphincterotomy, followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy after a few days should be done.
CBD stone detected during surgery (intraoperatively):
Laparoscopic cholecystectomy + laparoscopic CBD exploration should ideally be done in the same sitting to avoid the need for additional operative sitting and anaesthesia.
A transcystic approach is preferred usually.
If there is a small, friable cystic duct; numerous (more than eight) stones in the common bile duct; and large stones (>1 cm), laparoscopic choledocholithotomy is performed.
If laparoscopic choledocholithotomy exploration is not feasible, it would necessitate the need for an open CBD exploration.
A T-tube is placed in the CBD after laparoscopic choledocholithotomy or open CBD exploration. It is followed by a cholangiography to exclude retained stone.
CBD stone detected after surgery:
Endoscopic removal (ERCP) with sphincterotomy is usually the management of choice.
Solution to Question 21:
An 80-year-old woman with imaging showing a scleroatrophic gall bladder with impacted stones and a stone in the bile duct is suggestive of chronic cholelithiasis with choledocholithiasis. ERCP is the next line of management for this patient.
Choledocholithiasis is the presence of stone in the common bile duct (CBD) or biliary tree. It can be primary or secondary:
Primary stones are formed in the CBD or biliary tree itself and are rare.
Secondary stones are passed from the gallbladder to the CBD. They are easier to manage than primary stones.
It can be an asymptomatic and incidental finding or present with features such as jaundice (most common), abdominal pain, and fatigue. When there is inflammation of the biliary tree
(cholangitis), the patient will have intermittent pain, fever, and jaundice (Charcot's triad). Investigations:
Liver function tests will show elevated direct bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels.
Abdominal ultrasound is the first imaging modality done and may show gallstones and dilated bile duct (>8 mm).
CT is sensitive for CBD stones. It shows stones, location, ductal stricture or block, ducta dilatation, and intrahepatic biliary changes.
MRCP is highly sensitive and specific for CBD stones, but it is only diagnostic and intervention cannot be performed.
Management:
ERCP with sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice, followed by the removal of stones using a dormia basket or placement of a stent.
Despite ERCP being an invasive procedure, it has the advantage of being both a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure and is more suited for elderly patients who cannot tolerate anesthesia and surgery.
Other options:
Option A: Cholecystectomy is not recommended for elderly patients, owing to the risk of old age and associated anesthetic and surgical complications.
Option C: Wait and watch approach can be done for asymptomatic patients, and patients with smaller stones.
Option D: CT is sensitive for CBD stones, but it is only diagnostic and intervention cannot be performed.

Solution to Question 24:
A palpable gallbladder will not rule out gallstones in Mirizzi syndrome. It is an exception to Courvoisier's law.
Courvoisier's law states that in the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mild jaundice, the cause is unlikely to be gallstones. Its exceptions include:
Double impacted stones (stones in both the cystic duct and the distal common bile duct)
Primary CBD stone
Oriental cholangiohepatitis
Mirizzi's syndrome
In Mirizzi’s syndrome, gallstones become impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder due to inflammation. This causes common bile duct (CBD) obstruction and jaundice. The gallbladder is distended and may be palpable.
ERCP, PTC (Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography), or MRCP will usually demonstrate the characteristic extrinsic compression of the CBD.
Surgery consists of removing the cystic duct, diseased gallbladder, and the impacted stone. In patients whose gallbladder is densely adherent to the common bile duct, partial cholecystectomy should be done.
If left untreated, a fistula forms between the gallbladder and common bile duct
(cholecysto-choledochal fistula).

Gall bladder polyps are usually incidental findings during abdominal imaging. Most of them are benign and comprise cholesterol polyps, adenomyomas or inflammatory polyps. Adenomatous polyps are the most common neoplastic polyps. The majority of patients with polyps are stable and smaller polyps are kept under observation. Cholecystectomy is done for symptomatic patients (biliary colic, pancreatitis), patients >50 years, sessile polyps with thickening >4 mm and polyps >10 mm.
The risk factors for malignancy in an adenomatous polyp include age >50 years, size >10 mm, sessile polyp, documented increase in size, and coexistence with gallstones.

The most common type of gallbladder carcinoma is adenocarcinoma (80–90%). Squamous carcinomas also occur and are believed to arise from areas of mucosal squamous metaplasia.
Gallbladder carcinoma is a rare malignancy that is seen in the elderly. It is associated with a poor prognosis and is indistinguishable from cholecystitis or cholelithiasis. It is usually diagnosed when patients undergo cholecystectomy for gallstones.
Its clinical features include right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Jaundice is a late feature. CA 19-9 is elevated in the carcinoma gallbladder and is used for monitoring.
The preoperative diagnosis is often made on ultrasonography and followed up by a CT scan or MRI/Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography.
A percutaneous biopsy under radiological guidance is done for pathological examination. PET scanning helps in detecting metastatic disease.
In select cases, a laparoscopic examination is useful in staging the disease. Laparoscopy can also detect peritoneal or liver metastases. The most important prognostic factor is the depth of invasion (T-stage).

Solution to Question 1:
The presence of fever and chills, along with the MRCP showing multiple areas of intrahepatic beading is typical of primary sclerosing cholangitis.
Option B: Caroli's disease is a rare congenital condition characterized by irregular dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts with a normal extrahepatic duct system. It is common in both sexes and mostly presents before the age of 30 years with abdominal pain, cholangitis, or end-stage liver disease. MRCP shows irregular, cystic dilation of the large proximal intrahepatic bile ducts with a normal common bile duct.
Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is an autoimmune condition characterized by inflammatory strictures involving the intra and extra-hepatic biliary tree. It is a progressive condition that leads to secondary biliary cirrhosis.
MRCP or ERCP will show demonstrate multifocal, diffuse dilatation and strictures of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary trees, this pattern is a beading or chain of lakes appearance. Pseudodiverticula of extrahepatic bile ducts are pathognomic of PSC. MRCP is useful in diagnosis and surveillance, while ERCP is reserved for the treatment of dominant strictures and to exclude malignancy.
The below image shows a cholangiogram of primary sclerosing cholangitis:

The common age group of primary sclerosing cholangitis is 30-45 years. Men are affected twice as commonly as women. Two-thirds of these cases are associated with ulcerative colitis. It is also associated with Riedel’s thyroiditis and retroperitoneal fibrosis. 10–20% of patients develop cholangiocarcinoma.
Clinical features of a patient with PSC include pruritis, fever, chills, right upper quadrant discomfort, jaundice, and weight loss.
Liver function tests show a cholestatic pattern with an elevation of ALP and GGT and smaller rises in the aminotransferases. Bilirubin values may be variable.
Liver biopsy excludes other causes of cholestatic liver disease and defines the stage of PSC. It shows onion skin concentric periductal fibrosis. With disease progression, periportal fibrosis occurs, progressing to bridging necrosis, and eventually biliary cirrhosis.
Currently, there is no known effective medical therapy. Surgical management involving resection of extrahepatic biliary tree and hepaticojejunostomy has shown reasonable effects. For patients with advanced liver disease, liver transplantation is the only available option.
Other options:
Option C: Oriental cholangitis, also known as recurrent pyogenic cholangitis is characterized by recurrent attacks of cholangitis due to bile stasis and stone formation. Patients between 30-40 years and both sexes are equally affected. It is caused due to infections (liver flukes, E.coli, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, and Proteus). Patients present with Charcot's triad (intermittent fever, pain, and jaundice). MRCP shows intra or extrahepatic calculi, dilatation of ducts, and strictures.
Option D: Biliary carcinoma (cholangiocarcinoma) most commonly affects patients >60 years and presents with fever, abdominal pain, weight loss, and features of obstructive jaundice. MRCP
shows irregular narrowing of the bile duct involved by the tumor, with asymmetric upstream dilatation of the intrahepatic ducts.
Solution to Question 2:
Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct associated with bile leak is classified as Strasberg’s type C injury.
Biliary injury may occur post-laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The most common site of bile leak following cholecystectomy is the cystic duct.
MRCP is the gold standard for complete morphological evaluation of the biliary tree. MRCP with magnetic resonance angiography is more useful in cases of associated vascular injury. A HIDA scan can confirm the presence of a bile leak or biliary obstruction.
The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is widely used to anatomically define bile duct injuries.
Classification
Type A: Bile leak from cystic duct stump or a minor biliary radical in the gallbladder fossa
Type B: Occluded right posterior sectoral duct.
Type C: Bile leak from the divided right posterior sectoral duct.
Type D: Bile leak from the main bile duct without major tissue loss.
Type E: Injury to the main hepatic duct; classified according to the level of injury
E1: Transected main bile duct with a stricture more than 2cm from the hilus.
E2: Transected main bile duct with a stricture less than 2cm from the hilus
E3: Stricture of the hilus with right and left ducts in communication.
E4: Stricture of the hilus with separation of right and left hepatic ducts.
E5: Stricture of the right aberrant sectoral and main bile ducts.

Solution to Question 3:
Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the best investigation in a patient suspected of post-cholecystectomy biliary leaks.
Patients with post-cholecystectomy biliary leak usually present with fever, jaundice and abdominal pain. USG is used for an initial evaluation in such cases and can show a collection in the sub-hepatic space.
The most common bile leak following cholecystectomy is from the cystic duct. This can be treated by placing a biliary endoprosthesis (stent) in the common bile duct across the origin of the cystic duct.
MRCP shows fluid collections arising from bile leaks but cannot differentiate these from other causes of fluid collections.
ERCP is the best investigation as it has the advantage of being both diagnostic and
therapeutic. ERCP is useful post-cholecystectomy as there is a high likelihood of a retained stone and stone extraction and/or temporary stenting may be required.
HIDA scan is the most sensitive investigation for biliary leakage.
CT scan can show focal fluid collections, ascites, biliary obstruction, hepatic atrophy, signs of secondary biliary cirrhosis and any vascular injury.

In the case of a common bile duct injury with a leak and a patient presenting with signs of localized peritonitis, the next step of management is an ultrasound-guided aspiration. This will be followed by ERCP and stenting.
Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the most common cause of bile duct injury. Major biliary leakage is usually seen 2 to 10 days after cholecystectomy. Affected patients typically present with:
Fever
Abdominal pain
Bilious ascites
Mild jaundice
Leukocytosis
Elevations in the serum levels of ALP and GGT. Management of bile duct injury:
If the injury is identified during surgery:
Partial injury to the bile duct (<3mm) - repair the injury
Complete transection without loss of segment - anastomose over T-tube
Complete transection with loss of segment - close distal end and carry out Roux-en-Y hepaticoduodenostomy/jejunostomy
If the leak is suspected postoperatively:
Transabdominal ultrasonography is initially performed to assess the leak.
If the patient presents within 48 hours - Re-explore and repair
If the patient presents after 48 hours - USG-guided aspiration or pigtail catheter insertion.
This is followed by ERCP and stenting.

The most common cause of hemobilia is iatrogenic trauma.
Hemobilia is defined as bleeding into the biliary tree from abnormal communication between a blood vessel and bile duct.
Causes of hemobilia include:
Traumatic or operative injury to the liver or bile ducts
Intraductal rupture of a hepatic abscess or aneursm of the hepatic artery
Biliary or hepatic tumor hemorrhage
Mechanical complications of choledocholithiasis or hepatobiliary parasitism
Diagnostic procedures, such as liver biopsy, percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC),

Vascular disorders
Patients often present with a classic triad (Quincke's triad/Sandblom triad) of:
Biliary pain
Obstructive jaundice
Melena or occult blood in the stools
Investigation of choice: Arterial angiography (CT angiography) is the diagnostic procedure of choice.

Solution to Question 8:
Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the best investigation for the diagnosis of bilhemia.
Bilhemia is a condition in which bile flows into the bloodstream through the hepatic veins or portal vein branches. This flow occurs due to a high intrabiliary pressure, exceeding that of the venous system.
The cause can be the erosion of gallstones into the portal vein, or accidental/iatrogenic trauma. This condition can be fatal secondary to the embolization of large amounts of bile into the lungs. Usually, bile flow is low, and the fistulas close spontaneously.
Its clinical features include:
Rapidly progressive jaundice
Marked direct hyperbilirubinemia, without elevation of the hepatocellular enzyme levels.
Septicemia.
Diagnosis of bilhemia is best made by ERCP.
Treatment is directed at reducing the intrabiliary pressure through stent placement or sphincterotomy. Endovascular embolization can also be done.

Cholangiocellular carcinomas (CCCs) or cholangiocarcinomas are mucin-producing adenocarcinomas of the biliary duct system that may originate in the liver and extrahepatic bile ducts. Cholangiocarcinomas are encountered in three anatomic regions:
Intrahepatic
Hilar (65%) - also known as Klatskin tumours
Peripheral (30%)
The sclerosing variant of cholangiocarcinoma is the most common and most difficult to treat. The nodular variant is usually intrahepatic and presents as a mass lesion. The papillary variant is rare and is associated with favourable outcomes.

Associated anomalies include cardiac lesions, polysplenia, situs inversus, absent vena cava, and a preduodenal portal vein.
HIDA scan is the investigation of choice for EHBA. Intraoperative cholangiogram is the gold standard for diagnosis.

It may result in thrombosis of the mesenteric, portal, and renal veins which can be life-threatening as it can lead to haemorrhage and thromboembolism.
Option A: Tropical splenomegaly is massive splenic enlargement, which frequently occurs in the tropics due to malaria, kala-azar, and schistosomiasis.
Option C: Autosplenectomy is seen in sickle cell anemia. Splenomegaly is seen in thalassemia and hereditary spherocytosis.
Option D: Howell-Jolly bodies are the nuclear remnants present in the RBCs. They appear as dense blue colored circular inclusions as shown in the image below. They are usually seen in patients lacking normal spleen function (asplenia).

Solution to Question 9:
Splenomegaly is not a typical feature of splenic abscess.
Splenic abscesses manifest with vague abdominal pain, fever, peritonitis, and pleuritic chest pain. A splenic abscess may arise from an infected splenic embolus, or in association with:
Typhoid or paratyphoid fever
Osteomyelitis
Otitis media
Puerperal sepsis.
Solution to Question 10:
Overall, the most common indication for splenectomy is trauma to the spleen, whether external
(blunt or penetrating) or iatrogenic (e.g., during operative procedures for other reasons). The most common indication for:
Elective splenectomy - Haematological disorders such as ITP, TTP, etc.
Emergency splenectomy - Trauma
Splenectomy (overall) - Trauma.
Solution to Question 11:
Left lower lobe atelectasis is the most common complication after splenectomy.
Other complications of splenectomy include:
OPSI (Overwhelming post-splenectomy infection)is the most common fatal late complication of splenectomy.
Avascular necrosis of the greater curvature of the stomach is a rare complication that can occur after ligation of short gastric vessels.
Damage to the tail of the pancreas during surgery can lead to pancreatitis, a localized abscess, or pancreatic fistula.
Hemorrhage during the perioperative period etc.
Solution to Question 12:
Escherichia coli vaccination is not recommended in post-splenectomy patients.
Currently, the standard of care for post-splenectomy patients includes immunization with the following if the patient did not receive these before surgery:
Polyvalent pneumococcal vaccine (PPV23)
Haemophilus influenzae type B conjugate vaccine
Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine.
Solution to Question 13:
The risk of developing opportunistic post-splenectomy infection is greatest when splenectomy is done for haematological conditions than for post-trauma.
Opportunistic post-splenectomy infection is a major complication following splenectomy due to septicemia, which may result from an infection of:
Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
Neisseria meningitides
Haemophilus influenzae
Escherichia coli.
The risk of overwhelming sepsis is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy.
Hence, if an elective splenectomy is planned, consideration should be given to vaccinating against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years) at least 2 weeks before elective surgery.
In case of emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.
Solution to Question 14:
Kehr sign refers to referred pain in the tip of the left shoulder when firm pressure is applied over the left upper quadrant. It is also elicited by raising the left leg.
It is seen in the case of hemoperitoneum, especially due to splenic injury. It occurs due to the collection of blood below the diaphragm and irritation of the phrenic nerve.
Option A: Ballance sign is also seen in splenic injury. It is an area of percussive dullness in the left upper quadrant due to the coagulation of blood from the injured spleen.
Option B: Cullen sign refers to periumbilical bruising in cases of hemoperitoneum, especially those of pancreatic origin.

Option D: Grey Turner sign refers to bluish discolouration around flanks in case of hemoperitoneum especially acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

Solution to Question 15:
Splenic artery aneurysm is the commonest visceral artery aneurysm.
Splenic artery aneurysm occurs more commonly in females. It is usually situated in the main arterial trunk. It is usually asymptomatic unless it ruptures. During pregnancy, rupture is more common in the third trimester and in labour.
CT angiography is the investigation of choice. Not all diagnosed cases of splenic artery aneurysms need intervention.
Treatment should be considered in aneurysms larger than 2 cm in diameter.
In an elderly patient with a calcified aneurysm, there is less risk of rupture and observation may be preferred. In a younger patient with an asymptomatic aneurysm, surgery or interventional radiology is indicated.
In patients with pancreatic necrosis, the treatment should include drainage of the septic focus. The treatment comprises of:
Ligation of the proximal and distal ends of the sac
Embolization or endovascular stentin
Splenectomy with the removal of the artery

The most common splenic cyst is pseudocyst, secondary to trauma. These are termed pseudocysts due to their lack of cellular lining.
Splenic cysts are classified as either parasitic or non-parasitic:
Parasitic/hydatid cysts are the most common true/primary splenic cysts
Splenic pseudocysts are the most common non-parasitic splenic cysts and occur followin trauma
Epidermoid cysts are the most common non-traumatic, non-parasitic splenic cysts.

Option C: Ovarian carcinoma is the most common cause of isolated splenic metastasis
Option D: Lymphoma is the most common cause of neoplastic splenic enlargement and the most common malignant tumour associated with splenic involvement.
