Solution to Question 1:
The most common functioning endocrine tumor of the pancreas is insulinoma. It is a tumor arising from the beta cells of the pancreas.
The most common malignant functional neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is gastrinoma.
Solution to Question 2:
Insulinomas are distributed equally throughout the pancreas, despite the predominance of beta-cells in the body and tail.
The majority (90%) of insulinomas are benign and solitary, and only 10% are malignant and multifocal. Malignant insulinomas are usually found in association with multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome. Insulinomas are typically small, with an average size of 1.0 to 1.5 cm.
Insulinomas occur more commonly in females, between 40–60 years of age with the mean age of diagnosis at 45 years.
Solution to Question 3:
Elevated plasma levels of insulin is not a component of the triad. Whipple's triad is a clinical condition characterised by an insulin-producing tumour of the pancreas called insulinoma.
The components of the triad are:
Symptoms of hypoglycaemia after fasting or exercise.
Plasma glucose levels <2.8 mmol/L.
Relief of symptoms on intravenous administration of glucose.
Patients with insulinoma eat frequently to avoid hypoglycemic symptoms. Hence, weight loss is not a feature of insulinoma.
Solution to Question 4:
The gold standard for the diagnosis of insulinoma is the 72-hour monitored fasting test.
In this test, the levels of blood glucose, insulin, proinsulin, C peptide are measured in 1 to 2-hour intervals. When done so, a patient with insulinoma will have higher values of insulin, proinsulin, and C peptide which are expected to decrease in a normal person in response to the hypoglycemia due to fasting.
All patients should be advised to undergo surgical excision of insulinoma following the exclusion of diffuse abdominal metastases by ultrasound or CT scan.
Solution to Question 5:
Intra-operative ultrasound is the best method in localizing the site of the insulinoma.
This is a dynamic imaging modality that provides interactive and timely information during surgical procedures. This is essential for the identification of small tumors, especially within the pancreatic head or uncinate process.
Preoperatively, the site of the tumor can be assessed by endoscopic ultrasound or CT scan.
Solution to Question 6:
Recurrent hypoglycemic symptoms (dizziness) and low blood glucose with elevated insulin is suggestive of insulinoma. Tumour enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas.
Insulinomas of <2 cm in diameter without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are considered benign.
Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following:
Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail
Tumors of size >2 cm
Tumors within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct
Medical management to treat hyperinsulinism includes frequent intake of carbohydrate-rich meals, octreotide or diazoxide.
Solution to Question 7:
The patient is most likely suffering from MEN 1 syndrome. Gastrinoma is the most common functional entero-pancreatic tumor in MEN1. Superior and descending duodenum, head of the pancreas, and lymph nodes constitute the anatomical area called gastrinoma triangle, also known as the Passaro's triangle.
The triangle is bounded by the lines connecting:
The cystic duct
The junction between the second and third portions of the duodenum
The junction between the neck and body of the pancreas.

Solution to Question 8:
The most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome is the duodenum.
Gastrinoma is the most common pancreatic islet tumor in MEN 1 syndrome, arising from the G cells of the pancreas. Gastrinoma, associated with marked gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcers, is called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. The majority of gastrinomas occur in the gastrinoma (Passaro's) triangle.
In MEN 1, they often occur in patients <30 years. Patients present with abdominal pain (the most common symptom), diarrhea and steatorrhea.
Management:
Medical management for tumors <2 cm with proton-pump inhibitors.
Surgery for tumors >2 cm.
Proton-pump inhibitors with somatostatin analogues for advanced locoregional disease or metastasis.
Solution to Question 9:
Gastrinoma/Zollinger–Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a non–beta islet cell tumor of the pancreas. Option A: ZES is more common in males than in females.
Option B: At the time of diagnosis, >60% of tumors are malignant.
Option D: Surgical exploration should be performed in all patients without diffuse metastases, t remove known malignant and benign tumors.
Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome/gastrinoma. Here, the basal acid output (BAO) is increased. Hence, the BAO:MAO ratio is increased.
In these patients, there is gastrin hypersecretion that stimulates gastric acid secretion. This leads to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and
are refractory and multiple.
Abdominal pain is the most common complaint in these patients. However, diarrhea can occur due to:
Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa
Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach
Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH
Precipitation of bile salts.
The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions.
Gastric pH <2.5 and a serum gastrin concentration >1000 pg/mL confirm the diagnosis of Zollinger Ellison syndrome.
If the diagnosis remains in doubt, a secretin stimulation test is done. In this test, the fasting gastrin level is measured before secretin (2 IU/kg) is administered intravenously, and subsequent samples are obtained 2, 5, 10, and 20 minutes. Gastrin levels >200 pg/mL after administration of secretin are suggestive of gastrinoma.
Solution to Question 11:
The proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) dosage should be titrated to keep basal acid output <10 mEq/hr in this patient.
The target BAO is <5 mEq/hr if the patient has had a prior acid-reducing procedure.
Ideally, the dose of proton pump inhibitors is titrated using acid output in order to improve the healing rate of peptic ulcer disease, and to avert its complications.
Solution to Question 12:
Currently, the preoperative imaging study of choice for gastrinoma is somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (octreotide scan).
The majority of the gastrinomas are found within the Passaro’s triangle and can be detected by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS). However, it still misses many of the smaller lesions, and may confuse normal lymph nodes for gastrinomas.
If there is no tumor visible on EUS, a somatostatin receptor study is useful in identifying the location. When the pretest probability of gastrinoma is high, the sensitivity and specificity of this modality are almost 100%.
Solution to Question 13:
Non-functioning pancreatic endocrine tumors (NF-PETs) have a worse prognosis compared to functioning tumors.
They account for 60-90% of all neuroendocrine tumors. They are usually larger (>5cm), solitary, mostly in the head of the pancreas, malignant and metastatic. These do not cause any clinical symptoms.
They stain positive for immunohistochemical markers such as synaptophysin, chromogranin A (CgA), and neuron-specific enolase. Chromogranin A is used as a serum marker to monitor response to treatment and to detect recurrence.
Treatment is mainly surgical. It includes partial pancreaticoduodenectomy as well as the synchronous or metachronous resection of liver metastases.

The most probable diagnosis is somatostatinoma.
Somatostatin inhibits pancreatic and biliary secretions. Patients with somatostatinoma usually present with vague abdominal pain along with the triad of:
Gallstones - due to bile stasis
Diabetes - due to inhibition of insulin secretion
Steatorrhea - due to inhibition of pancreatic exocrine secretion and bile secretion.

Vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumor (VIPoma) is also known as Verner–Morrison syndrome/WDHA syndrome. WDHA stands for:

A – Achlorhydria
Metabolic acidosis from fluid and bicarbonate loss is common in VIPoma.

Solution to Question 1:
Pancreas divisum is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas.
During embryogenesis, the developing pancreatic ducts usually fuse in such a way that most of the dorsal duct drains into the proximal part of the ventral duct. The proximal portion of the dorsal duct usually persists as an accessory duct.
In about 10% of the population, there is a failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds leading to a condition called pancreatic divisum (pancreas divisum). Pancreatic drainage is accomplished mainly through the accessory papilla.
Since most of the pancreatic exocrine secretions exit through the dorsal duct, the pancreas divisum can lead to a partial obstruction due to the small minor papilla, leading to the development of relapsing acute or chronic pancreatitis

Solution to Question 2:
MRCP is more advantageous than ERCP in diagnosing pancreatic divisum. This is because, MRCP can delineate the entire dorsal pancreatic duct, whereas ERCP can assess only the ventral duct on cannulation of the major duodenal papilla.
The diagnosis of pancreatic divisum can also be made by EUS, or ERCP, augmented by injection of secretin if necessary.
Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stenting of the minor papilla relieve the symptoms. Surgical intervention may involve sphincteroplasty, pancreatojejunostomy (Puestow procedure), or even resection of the pancreatic head.
The image given below shows an MRCP done for a case of pancreatic divisum.

Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of annular pancreas, which is a type of developmental anomaly leading to duodenal compression. Laparotomy with a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas is the gold standard test for an annular pancreas, not an MRCP.
The annular pancreas is due to result of the failure of the complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud. During development, a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum.

It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal atresia and is, therefore, more prevalent in children with Down’s syndrome.
Duodenal obstruction typically causes non-projectile, non-bilious vomiting in neonates.
Plain abdominal radiographs may demonstrate the classic double bubble sign. But it is
non-specific for the annular pancreas. Despite many advances in diagnostic techniques such as CT scan, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), MRCP, and ERCP, the gold standard test for diagnosing AP remains to be laparotomy. It involves a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas.
The treatment for an annular pancreas is a duodenal bypass procedure (duodenoduodenostomy).
Solution to Question 4:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Rovsing sign and Aaron sign are seen in acute appendicitis.
Rovsing sign: Pain in the right lower quadrant during palpation of the left lower quadrant.
Aaron sign: Pain or pressure in the epigastrium or anterior chest with firm pressure applied to McBurney’s point.
In severe acute pancreatitis, the injured pancreas releases pancreatic enzymes that cause fat necrosis and inflammation, occasionally resulting in peri-pancreatic bleeding. The resulting fluid collection can travel via an anatomical defect of the transversalis fascia. This accumulates at various sites and shows discoloration of the skin.
Cullen's sign: If the blood diffuses from the retroperitoneum along with the gastrohepatic and falciform ligaments to the umbilicus, it results in bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
Grey Turner sign: If the blood diffuses from the posterior pararenal space to the lateral edge of the quadratus lumborum muscle, it results in bluish discoloration of the flanks
F x sign: Pooling of retroperitoneal hemorrhage at the inguinal ligament shows discoloration below the inguinal ligament
Bryant sign: Pooling of blood at the scrotum

Hypercalcemia may cause acute pancreatitis. Hypocalcemia is a complication of acute pancreatitis.

The given clinical scenario of chronic pancreatitis with SPINK1 mutation is suggestive of tropical pancreatitis (nutritional pancreatitis). Tropical pancreatitis is histologically indistinguishable from chronic alcoholic pancreatitis.
Normally, if trypsinogen does become prematurely activated within the pancreas, it is inhibited by SPINK1 and then gets destroyed. A loss-of-function mutation in SPINK1 affects this process and predisposes to tropical pancreatitis.
Tropical pancreatitis is a form of idiopathic pancreatitis that begins at a young age and is usually seen in Indonesia, southern India (Kerala), and tropical Africa. It is associated with a high incidence of diabetes mellitus (a brittle form of pancreatogenic diabetes) and stone

Malnutrition
Ingestion of cyanogenic glycosides in cassava
Exposure to hydrocarbons released from kerosene or paraffin lamps
Tropical pancreatitis is histologically indistinguishable from chronic alcoholic pancreatitis.

PRSS1 mutation accounts for about two-thirds of cases of hereditary pancreatitis. There is an increased risk of developing pancreatic cancer, particularly if the patient smokes tobacco.

The diagnostic test with the best sensitivity and specificity for chronic pancreatitis is the secretin test.
Secretin is a hormone secreted by the small intestines. It normally stimulates the pancreas to secrete a fluid with a high concentration of bicarbonate. Secretin stimulation test is a test that measures the ability of the pancreas to respond to secretin.
In order to perform the test, a tube is passed into the duodenum. Secretin is administered intravenously and the contents of the duodenal secretions are aspirated and analyzed over a period of about 2 hours. The test becomes abnormal when  60% of the pancreatic exocrine function has been lost. This usually correlates well with the onset of chronic abdominal pain.

Reverses exocrine insufficiency
Prevents secondary complications such as metabolic bone disease due to inadequate absorption of the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K

Pancreatic enzyme supplementation is done with meals. Non-enteric-coated tablets are degraded by gastric juice and the released enzymes inhibit cholecystokinin (CCK) secretion. This, in turn, decreases the pancreatic secretion and thereby reduces the pain caused due to the increased accumulation of the secretions within the pancreatic duct.
Enteric-coated tablets are not degraded in the proximal small intestine and, hence, might not be effective in reducing CCK secretion and relieving pain.

Pseudocysts are post-inflammatory cysts that arise following an attack of mild acute pancreatitis. Formation of a pseudocyst requires 4 weeks or more from the onset of acute pancreatitis. They are also the most common complication of chronic pancreatitis.
Pseudocysts are usually solitary and most commonly seen in the lesser omental sac. The most common artery involved is the splenic artery.

GI bleeding
Fistula formation
Peritonitis
Obstructive jaundice
Bowel obstruction

Haemosuccus pancreaticus, also known as pseudohaemobilia, is a rare cause of GI bleeding, due to blood originating from the pancreatic duct into the duodenum via the ampulla of Vater. It is usually caused by the erosion of a pancreatic pseudocyst into the splenic artery.
In hemosuccus pancreatitis, abdominal pain radiating to the back accompanied by melena is the most typical presentation. The pain usually has an up and down pattern, which means it changes in intensity over time. This is due to the transient closure of pancreatic ducts. Other features include:
Hematochezia
Hematemesis
Anemia
Jaundice
A palpable pulsatile mass with a thrill murmur
Retroperitoneal bleeding
Laboratory values show elevated lipase and low hemoglobin levels. The diagnosis is mainly through imaging modalities like upper GI endoscopy, ERCP, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), and contrast-enhanced CT scan.
CT angiography is the gold standard diagnostic tool. It helps to localize the site of bleed and plan the management accordingly.
Once the bleeding source is identified, hemodynamically stable patients are managed by coil embolization, balloon tamponade, or stent placement.

Solution to Question 1:
Mucinous cystadenoma of the pancreas is a premalignant condition.
Mucinous cystadenoma or mucinous cystic neoplasm (MCN) is a benign tumor of the pancreas with high risk of malignancy. They are commonly seen in perimenopausal women, and about
two-thirds are located in the body or tail of the pancreas.
MCNs are mostly incidental findings. When symptoms are present, they are usually nonspecific and include upper abdominal discomfort, early satiety, or weight loss.
The cysts are lined by tall columnar epithelium. MCN's contain mucin-producing epithelium and are identified histologically by the presence of mucin-rich cells and ovarian-like stroma. Staining for estrogen and progesterone is positive in most cases.
Malignant transformation of MCN is common with large tumors and old patients. This is due to a stepwise accumulation of mutations (K-ras, p53).

The intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm can be diagnosed with the following findings

Bulging ampulla of Vater (fish-mouth sign)
Dilated pancreatic duct
Mucin secretion from the opening
Equal distribution is seen between males and females in IPMN. Patients are usually in their seventh or eighth decade of life and present with abdominal pain or recurrent pancreatitis. This is caused by the obstruction of the pancreatic duct by thick mucin. Some patients have symptoms secondary to pancreatic insufficiencies like steatorrhea, diabetes, and weight loss.
IMPNs are of three types:
Branch-duct IPMN (BD-IPMN) - affects only the small side branches. It is less frequently associated with malignancy.
Main duct IPMN (MD-IPMN) - Affects the main pancreatic duct. Malignant transformation is commonly seen.
Mixed-type IPMN - side-branch IPMNs that extend into the main duct

Solution to Question 1:
The kidney has an extensive lymphatic network.
It begins in three plexuses which drain into the lateral aortic nodes. These are located around the renal tubules, under the renal capsule, and in the perirenal fat.
The renal arteries are end arteries without collateral circulation. The right renal artery is longer than the left renal artery. This is due to the position of the abdominal aorta which is slightly to the
left of the midline.
The left renal vein is much longer than the right renal vein. This is due to the position of the IVC which is slightly to the right of the midline.
The line of Brodel is the avascular plane of the kidney. It lies between anterior and posterior segmental branches. It is an important access route for both open and endoscopic surgical procedures, as it minimizes the risk of damage to major arterial branches.

Solution to Question 2:
The iliac fossa on the posterior abdominal wall is the usual site chosen for transplantation of the kidney.
The left kidney is preferred for transplantation because the left renal vein is longer.
In the case of a deceased donor, the arterial graft is traced until the aorta which makes it longer, and hence end-to-side anastomosis is possible. Whereas, in the case of a live donor, the arterial graft cannot be extended until the aorta.

Solution to Question 3:
The given scenario with intravenous pyelogram showing flower vase sign points to a diagnosis of horseshoe kidney. Division of the relatively avascular isthmus between the kidneys is usually not indicated. This is because it can lead to an increased risk of urinary fistula.
Horseshoe kidneys are the most common fusion defects of the kidney, characterized by abnormalities in the position, rotation, and vascular supply of the kidney.
The fused portion lies adjacent to the L3 or L4 vertebra just below the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery. Ascent of the fused kidneys is prevented by the inferior mesenteric artery. Adrenal glands remain in the normal position.
There is a 2:1 male predominance. It is also commonly associated with renal cell carcinoma, Wilms tumor, multicystic dysplastic kidney, and Turner’s syndrome.
Patients may be asymptomatic or may present with:
Dull renal pain
Abdominal lump
Urinary tract infections
Increased angulation of ureters resulting in -
Nephrolithiasis
Hydronephrosis
Radiological diagnosis is by intravenous pyelogram which shows flower vase sign or handshake sign.
Symptomatic management is preferred. Heminephrectomy is usually not indicated for horseshoe kidneys with unilateral RCC/ Wilms tumor. This is because it can result in devascularisation due to the unpredictable blood supply of the horseshoe kidney from nearby major vessels.
Note: Division of the relatively avascular isthmus between the kidneys is only indicated in the course of surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm.

The below CECT shows a fusion defect of the kidneys.

Solution to Question 4:
The given scenario and intravenous urogram showing a "drooping lily" sign point to a diagnosis of a duplex kidney.
It refers to the presence of duplicated ureters or collecting systems. This is due to the incomplete fusion of the upper and lower pole of the kidney. Duplex kidneys have two separate pelvicalyceal systems draining single renal parenchyma.
The lower pole ureter is normally inserted into the bladder. However, the upper pole ureter has an ectopic insertion. It crosses the lower pole ureter to open inferior and medial to the normal site of insertion (Weigert–Meyer rule). This results in reflux and incontinence.
Option B: In retrocaval ureter, the IVC presses on the right ureter as it lies behind the IVC. Intravenous urogram shows reversed ‘J’/ fish hook ureter.

Solution to Question 5:
The given scenario with CT showing multiple cysts in the kidneys and liver points to a diagnosis of adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). In such patients, decompression or deroofing of the cysts (Rovsing’s procedure) cannot restore normal renal function.
ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1(chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4).
The disease does not usually manifest before 30 years of age, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed. The progression of the disease is faster in males.
Hypertension is the most common presentation. Renal manifestations of ADPKD include:
Flank/loin pain - either due to hemorrhage inside cysts or due to renal stones (most commonly uric acid stones)
Irregular upper quadrant renal mass
Hematuria
Uremia
Renal failure (seen in 10-15% of the patients who receive hemodialysis)
Intravenous pyelography shows characteristic spider leg sign, as a result of stretched calyces due to multiple cysts. Nephrogram shows a swiss cheese appearance. On prenatal USG, the presence of either > 3 cysts in unilateral kidneys or > 2 cysts in each kidney is suggestive of PKD.
Treatment includes:
Long-term dialysis
Renal transplantation
Vasopressin V2 receptor antagonists
Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) occurs secondary to a mutation of the PKHD1 gene. The severe form manifests in-utero or during infancy; milder cases can manifest later in childhood. 50% of affected newborns die in the first few days of life.
Solution to Question 6:
The given image showing dilated clubbed calyces with stricture of the left ureteropelvic junction points to a diagnosis of hydronephrosis.
Hydronephrosis refers to the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system caused by a partial or complete blockage of urinary flow.
Investigations:
Ultrasound is the least invasive technique for diagnosing hydronephrosis.
Retrograde pyelography is rarely indicated but will confirm the site of obstruction before corrective surgery.
Intravenous urogram (IVU) is helpful only if the obstructed kidney is functional. In IVU, the extrarenal pelvis is dilated and the minor calyces lose their normal cupping. In early stages, there is blunting of calyces followed by its clubbing in the late stages.
A renal isotope scan (DTPA or MAG-3) is the best modality to confirm the obstructive dilatation of the collecting system.
Solution to Question 7:
Ureteropelvic junction obstruction is the most common cause of hydronephrosis found on prenatal ultrasound.
The causes of UPJ obstruction can be:
Intrinsic - due to an adynamic or stenotic segment of the proximal ureter
Extrinsic - due to accessory renal arteries
Treatment includes Anderson Hynes dismembered pyeloplasty.
Option B: Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is the second most common cause of hydronephrosis. In VUR, the valve that prevents the backflow of urine from the bladder into the ureter is defective.
Option C: Ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter, thought to result from the persistence of the membrane between the ureteral bud and urogenital sinus. IVU shows cobra head/ adder head appearance.
Option D: Posterior urethral valve is an obstructing membrane in the posterior male urethra as a result of abnormal in-utero development. It is the most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male newborns.
Note: Renal stones are the most common cause of acquired unilateral hydronephrosis.
Solution to Question 8:
The given scenario is suggestive of a ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction. The investigation of choice for UPJ obstruction is 99mTc-MercaptoAcetyl-triGlycine (MAG3) scan. Delayed clearance of contrast or the radiotracer implies obstruction.
Renal isotope scans have replaced intravenous pyelogram as the diagnostic modality of choice in UPJ obstruction.

The given scenario of hydronephrosis with renal pain relieved after the passage of a large amount of urine is suggestive of Dietl's crisis.
It is defined as intermittent ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction causing episodic abdominal pain and nausea, most often due to an aberrant accessory renal artery or vein.
In an acute phase of ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, loin swelling occurs along with renal pain due to the retention of urine in the kidney. When the obstruction is relieved, the patient passes a large amount of urine, the swelling is reduced and the pain disappears. This is termed Dietl's crisis.
In the majority of cases, pyeloplasty results in the complete resolution of symptoms.
Solution to Question 10:
Hypercalciuria, hyperoxaluria, and hyperuricosuria are risk factors for calcium stone formation.
Risk factors for calcium stone formation include:
High urine concentration of calcium, oxalate, or uric acid
Low urine concentration of renal stone inhibiting factors such as citrate and magnesium
Abnormal urine pH
Renal stone formation is governed by factors promoting and inhibiting stone formation. Stone formation occurs when the concentration product is more than the formation product i.e., CP > FP, where:
Concentration product (CP) - the amount of solute in solution
Formation product (FP) - maximum concentration of solute in solution after taking into account stone inhibiting factors.

Solution to Question 12:
The given scenario and X-Ray KUB showing staghorn appearance points to a diagnosis of struvite stones. Struvite stone is produced in alkaline urine.
It is commonly associated with infections with urea-splitting organisms like Proteus and Klebsiella species. Increased metabolism of urea results in alkalinity of the urine.
Struvite is a triple-phosphate calculus (calcium, ammonium, and magnesium phosphate). The calculus may enlarge to fill most of the collecting system, forming a staghorn calculus.
These stones are dirty-white in color, and grossly smooth in texture. Rectangular or coffin lid appearance is seen on microscopic examination.
Solution to Question 13:
Acetohydroxamic acid is used for the treatment of struvite stone.
It is a urease inhibitor. The urease enzyme generates ammonia from urea, elevating the pH of the urine. This favors the production of struvite stones. Thus, the use of AHA(Acetohydroxamic acid) causes complete, noncompetitive inhibition of urease production, thereby slowing struvite stone growth. Owing to its side-effects, the use of this drug has been restricted in cases of recurrent UTIs, and those intolerant or who refuse surgical management.
It can also be used for oral chemolysis and can potentiate the action of antibiotics.
Solution to Question 14:
In the given scenario since the stone is radiolucent, it is most likely to be uric acid stone.
Uric acid stones are preferentially formed in acidic urine. It is commonly associated with disorders of purine metabolism such as gout, and tumor lysis syndrome. On microscopic examination, the crystals appear as glass shards.
Patients with recurrent uric acid stones are treated with Allopurinol.
Note: 90% of the renal stones are radio-opaque, while 80% of gall bladder stones are radiolucent.
Solution to Question 15:
The urine microscopy shows the presence of hexagonal-shaped stones which are likely to be cystine stones.
These stones are commonly found in acidic urine. Recurrent stones are treated using D-penicillamine.
Solution to Question 16:
A low calcium diet has not shown any significant benefit in the prevention of calcium stone formation, compared to a normocalcemic diet.
However, a diet rich in calcium rather binds with dietary oxalate and reduces dietary absorption of oxalate. This effect leads to a lower risk of calcium oxalate stone formation in the kidneys.
Option B: Uric acid crystallization and stone formation take place in acidic pH. Therefore, urinary alkalinization by potassium citrate reduces the risk of urate stone formation.
Option C: Cystine stones are usually formed in presence of cystinuria. Initial treatment options to prevent recurrent cystine stone formation includes increased fluid intake and urinary alkalinization (e.g citrate). If this therapy fails, d-penicillamine can be used.
Option D: Pyridoxine acts as a cofactor in the oxalic acid metabolism process and helps in the reduction of endogenous oxalate levels. Several studies have mentioned the role of pyridoxine in the reduction of oxalate stone formation.
Solution to Question 17:
Indinavir (a protease-inhibitor) is most likely to be responsible for renal stones in a patient on HAART. It has the highest incidence of nephrolithiasis among anti-retroviral drugs.
Indinavir is released in high concentration in the urine due to poor solubility in the physiologic pH. Consequently, patients develop stones that are principally composed of indinavir or of a mixture of indinavir and other substances, such as calcium oxalate.
Other urolithogenic drugs are:
Antihypertensives - furosemide, bumetanide (loop diuretics), triamterene (potassium-sparing diuretic)
Decongestant - ephedrine
Expectorant - guaifenesin
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - acetazolamide, topiramate, and zonisamide
Newer antiretroviral agents - lopinavir-ritonavir, ritonavir-boosted atazanavir, nelfinavir, and amprenavir
Solution to Question 18:
Ammonium urate stones are most likely to be seen in patients with laxative abuse.
Loss of potassium and sodium in laxative abuse causes intracellular acidosis, which increases the production of ammonia in urine. Dehydration and sodium loss further exacerbate hypokalemia and reduces the urinary volume, resulting in hyperuricemia. Highly concentrated uric acid and ammonia promote the formation of ammonium urate stones.
These are also associated with inflammatory bowel disease, chronic diarrhea, ileostomy, recurrent urinary tract infection and recurrent uric acid stone formation.

Solution to Question 1:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pyelonephritis. Patients with acute pyelonephritis are more likely to have struvite stones, not uric acid stones. This is because of infection
with urea-splitting organisms such as proteus that release ammonia. This makes the urine alkaline and promotes the formation of struvite stones.
Acute pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection causing inflammation of the kidneys. Ascending infection in the urinary tract is the most common route. It is more common in young, sexually active women. Up to 50% of children with urinary infections have an underlying anatomical abnormality (e.g., reflux or obstruction).
Clinical features include:
Prodromal symptoms such as headache, lassitude, vomiting
Flank pain, fever, rigor
Pyuria and occasionally hematuria
CECT abdomen is the investigation of choice to rule out pyonephrosis.
The mainstay of treatment is broad-spectrum antibiotics to prevent renal scarring. Surgery is indicated only if antibiotic therapy fails.
Solution to Question 2:
The given history with Murphy's punch sign positive, and streaks of gas on CECT abdomen point to a diagnosis of emphysematous pyelonephritis. Escherichia coli is the most common causative organism.
Emphysematous pyelonephritis is associated with an acute necrotizing infection of the kidney by gas-producing organisms that occurs predominantly in diabetic patients. E. coli produces carbon dioxide by the fermentation of sugar.
Patients frequently present with sepsis and ketoacidosis. It can be associated with tenderness at the costovertebral angle known as Murphy's punch sign.
CECT abdomen shows an enlarged destructed renal parenchyma with small linear streaks of gas.
Treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics with drainage. In patients who fail to respond to treatment, nephrectomy is considered.
Note: Clostridium species are the most common causative organisms in emphysematous cholecystitis.
Murphy's punch sign is also seen in infection, inflammation, or obstruction of the kidney. The below image shows the costovertebral angle formed between the lower border of the 12th rib and the vertebral column.

Solution to Question 3:
The given scenario with CECT abdomen showing bear paw sign is suggestive of xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XGP). Subcapsular nephrectomy is the preferred treatment in patients with XGP.
It is a form of chronic pyelonephritis seen most frequently in middle-aged diabetic women and, rarely, in children. XGP is most commonly caused by proteus followed by E. coli. The disease is usually unilateral and is associated with prolonged obstructing nephrolithiasis.
CECT abdomen shows dilated and enlarged renal pelvis and calyxes showing a multiloculated appearance. This is referred to as the bear paw sign. Histology shows foamy, lipid-laden macrophages.

Putty kidney refers to the amorphous dystrophic calcification seen over the entire kidney during the end stage of genitourinary TB.
Genitourinary tuberculosis is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream. It occurs either due to reinfection or reactivation of old TB.
CT is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB.
ATT is given to all patients with genitourinary TB. Nephrectomy is the preferred treatment in patients with putty/ cement kidneys.

The given scenario and CT findings are suggestive of a diagnosis of angiomyolipoma.
Angiomyolipoma (AML) is a benign neoplasm of the kidney. It contains blood vessels, smooth muscles, and fat, and arises from perivascular epithelioid cells. It can occur in isolated forms or may be associated with tuberous sclerosis.
Patients can either be asymptomatic or may present with abdominal pain or a lump. Some patients may also present with massive hemorrhage referred to as Wunderlich’s syndrome. Lenk’s triad seen in patients with Wunderlich’s syndrome includes:
Abdominal mass
Abdominal pain
Shock
Due to the presence of abundant fat tissue, they can be easily identified on CT scans. Immunohistochemistry is positive for HMB 45. Treatment includes:
Asymptomatic tumors and tumors less than 4 cm in size - Observation with serial CECT
Symptomatic tumors and tumors more than 4 cm in size - Partial nephrectomy/ nephron-sparing surgery
Bleeding tumors - Angioembolization followed by partial nephrectomy Everolimus is FDA approved for the treatment of AMLs.

Metastasis to the lungs occurs early in Wilms tumor. Liver, bone, and brain metastasis is rare.
Wilms tumor or nephroblastoma is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood. It is commonly seen in children between 2-5 years of age. More than one-third of the cases contain precursor lesions known as nephrogenic rests.
Asymptomatic abdominal mass discovered incidentally is the most common presentation. Patients may also present with:
Abdominal pain
Gross painless hematuria
Fever
Hypertension
Most unilateral tumors are treated by chemotherapy (cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and dactinomycin) followed by nephrectomy.
Radical nephrectomy is the standard surgical procedure done. Partial nephrectomy is considered if all the following conditions are met:
The tumor involves only one pole of the kidney
No evidence of collecting system or vascular involvement
The involved kidney has an appreciable function
There are clear margins between tumor and surrounding structures
It is done for children with bilateral disease or with a solitary kidney. Preoperative chemotherapy can be used in these cases to induce tumor shrinkage.

USG with doppler study of renal veins - for evaluation of the collecting system and to look for tumor thrombi in renal veins and inferior vena cava
CECT abdomen - to identify the extent of the disease, to access the contralateral kidney, and for metastasis
MRI - not used routinely as it requires sedation
Positron emission tomography(PET) scan - to identify regional spread and metastatic lesions
Diagnosis should be made by imaging studies and it is confirmed after nephrectomy. A biopsy is discouraged in this condition as it results in disease upstaging. Only in cases with atypical presentation such as older age, signs of infection, etc, or with unusual imaging findings a core needle biopsy via the posterior approach can be performed.
Note: Neuroblastoma also presents similar to Wilms tumor. It is commonly seen in children of preschool age. Affected children commonly present with a palpable abdominal mass and the most common site of the tumor is the retroperitoneum. Therefore, this disease becomes an important differential diagnosis. So we should also test for the presence of vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA) in this patient to exclude this tumor.

The congenital anomaly seen in the above image is exstrophy of the bladder (ectopia vesicae). It is associated with epispadias, not hypospadias.
Bladder exstrophy refers to herniation of the urinary bladder through an anterior abdominal wall defect. The bladder is open and exposed on the outside of the abdomen. The male to female ratio is 4:1. Chronic exposure of the bladder to the external environment can lead to adenocarcinoma of the bladder.

Epispadias

Management involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia. Closure of the abdominal and bladder wall is done in the first year of life. This often requires an iliac
osteotomy to relax the tension on the bladder and repair the abdominal wall during wound-healing.

The given clinical scenario with continuous dribbling of urine, in spite of regular voiding, is suggestive of an ectopic ureter.
Ectopic ureter is a congenital anomaly that occurs as a result of abnormal caudal migration of the ureteral bud during its insertion into the urinary bladder. They are usually associated with duplex ureters and drain from the upper pole of the kidney.
It is more common in females. The ectopic ureter usually opens into the urethra, vagina, and perineum. Hence, female patients present with constant urinary dripping all day, even though the child voids regularly (Paradoxical incontinence). It can cause hydroureteronephrosis and recurrent UTI.
In males, the ectopic ureter opens always above the external urethral sphincter. Hence they are usually continent. However, it can cause other complications such as orchitis and epididymitis.
Management involves re-implantation of the ureter into the bladder to treat incontinence and preserve renal functions. If the kidney is severely affected, partial nephrectomy is helpful.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bacterial prostatitis and should be managed by antibiotics.
A rigorous and prolonged treatment for 2-6 weeks with an antibiotic that penetrates the prostate wall is indicated (trimethoprim, ciprofloxacin or aminoglycoside). Incomplete infection eradication lead to recurrent attacks and chronic prostatitis.
Acute bacterial prostatitis is usually caused by an ascending urinary tract infection (UTI) or reflux of infected urine into prostatic ducts. The most common organism is Escherichia coli. An associated increase in levels of PSA(>4ng/ml) may be present due to prostate inflammation.
Catheterization and prostatic massage are contraindicated in patients with suspected acute prostatitis, as they increase the chance for bacteremia and sepsis. Instead, suprapubic tap should be performed to alleviate retention.
Chronic bacterial prostatitis is the sequela of inadequately treated acute prostatitis. Diagnosis includes:
Three-glass urine test - If the first glass with the initial urine sample is clear, but the second and third samples contain prostatic threads and leukocytes, it indicates the presence of prostatitis.
Digital rectal examination - Prostate may be normal, boggy, or tender.
Prostatic fluid examination - post-prostatic massage fluid shows pus cells and bacteria.

It is commonly caused by an ascending urethral infection or reflux of infected urine into prostatic ducts. Sexually transmissible infections and other urinary pathogens, such as Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus faecalis may also be responsible.
The patient presents with fever, perineal pain, chills and rigor, and dysuria. Per rectal examination will reveal a tender, boggy prostate. Care should be taken to avoid aggressive palpation or prostatic massage as it can lead to bacterial dissemination and sepsis.

Patients with systemic signs of infection should be admitted for IV antibiotics, hydration, and monitoring of laboratory parameters.
Patients who have no signs of systemic infection, who can tolerate oral intake, and who have no urinary retention can be treated with oral antibiotics. Antibiotics are given for 2-6 weeks to ensure

Solution to Question 1:
The most common site of urethral stricture is the bulbar urethra.
A urethral stricture is a narrowing of the urethra caused by scarring, which functionally causes obstructive voiding dysfunction of the lower urinary tract.
The most common cause of urethral stricture is trauma. It can also be iatrogenic due urethral catheterization and infections.
These patients present with features of the hesitancy of micturition, straining to void, and poor urinary stream.
The most common complication of urethral stricture is urinary tract infection.

The given image shows retrograde cystourethrogram with findings consistent with penile urethral stricture.
The male urethra can be visualized by retrograde urethrography (RGU) or voiding cystourethrogram (VCU), also known as micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).
In RGU, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penile urethra and bulbar urethra). It is helpful for diagnosing anterior urethral abnormalities.
The following image shows an RGU with bulbar urethral stricture:

In VCU, after injecting contrast into the bladder using a Foleys catheter, the posterior urethra (membranous urethra and prostatic urethra) is visualized during micturition. It is helpful for diagnosing posterior urethral abnormalities and bladder abnormalities. It is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) and posterior urethral valve.

The management of a urethral stricture depends on the site, the length, and the cause of the stricture. They include:
Endoscopic urethrotomy - The stricture is released using a knife passed through a rigid urethroscope.
Urethroplasty - Excision of the stenosed length of the urethra and re-anastomosis is done.
A buccal mucosa graft can be used to bridge the gap. It is considered when a stricture is due to rauma or recurred following endoscopic treatment.
Urethral dilation - The urethra is stretched using urethral dilators. This is a blind procedure and it can cause injury. Hence, it is not done frequently.
Intermittent self-dilatation - In patients with recurrent strictures who are unable to undergo urethroplasty, then intermittent self-dilatation with soft hydrophilic catheters is done on a daily basis.

The given clinical scenario with the USG showing the key-hole sign is suggestive of the posterior urethral valve (PUV). It is seen due to dilatation of the bladder and the proximal urethra.
The posterior urethral valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit, which lies just distal to the verumontanum. They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow.
The posterior urethral valve is the most common congenital cause of bladder outlet obstruction in males. PUV is classified into three types based on Young's classification.

The most common cause of erectile dysfunction (ED) is stress. It can also be associated with diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and smoking.
The most common pathological cause of ED is vascular disease affecting the penile arterial blood flow.
Evaluation of ED involves confirmation of the diagnosis by history taking, assessing the patient for underlying risk factors, and physical examination of the genitalia. Measurement of the blood pressure and assessment of the secondary sexual characteristics is also done.
Biochemical assessment of the blood sugar, the serum lipid profile, and the serum testosterone is done in all cases.

Circumcision is the surgical removal of the foreskin that covers the glans penis. Indications of circumcision in children:

Solution to Question 12:
The clinical history and the image showing swollen glans are suggestive of paraphimosis. If manual reduction of the skin is unsuccessful, a dorsal slit procedure should be performed.
Paraphimosis is the inability to place back the retracted preputial skin. This creates a ring-like constriction, and the glans tend to be swollen, and edematous, with severe pain and tenderness. Paraphimosis is precipitated after sexual intercourse or iatrogenically after urethral catheterization.
The first line of treatment includes manual reduction of the skin by applying lignocaine jelly. Ice bags and injection of a solution of hyaluronidase in normal saline may help to reduce the swelling.
If this fails, an initial dorsal slit is made to relieve the edema and compression. Antibiotics and analgesics are also given. Circumcision is performed after 3 weeks.
Solution to Question 13:
Penile deformity, painful erection, and palpable penile plaques are features associated with Peyronie's disease. Nesbitt’s procedure is the most common procedure done for this condition.
Peyronie's disease is caused due to injury to tunica albuginea resulting in microhemorrhages. This leads to excess collagen deposition, calcification, and penile plaques. Hence, the penis
bends towards the side of the plaque. This causes difficulty during sexual intercourse. It is also associated with Dupuytren's contracture.


Nesbitt's procedure corrects the deformity by plicating the opposite side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis. This procedure is done once the active phase subsides as the bend increases during the active phase (18-24 months).

The Heineke-Mikulicz principle is used in both preputioplasty and frenuloplasty.
The Heineke-Mikulicz principle involves the use of a longitudinal incision followed by a transverse closure, or vice-versa. In preputioplasty, it allows for the retraction of the foreskin, and in frenuloplasty, it allows the lengthening of the frenulum.
Heineke-Mikulicz's pyloroplasty also uses the same principle. Here, a longitudinal incision is done through the pylorus, with extension to the duodenum and gastric antrum. This incision is then closed transversely. It is done for gastric outlet obstruction and along with highly selective vagotomy.

In penile carcinoma, total amputation of the penis is done if the stump is < 2cm.
The investigation of choice for penile carcinoma is a biopsy from the primary tumor. For staging, MRI is the investigation of choice.
The first lymph node to be involved is the superficial inguinal lymph node and thus, the sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is helpful for evaluating the spread of penile cancer.
The management is divided into treatment of the primary tumour and the treatment of the lymph nodes.
The main principles of penile cancer surgery are to remove a 1cm margin of normal tissue and have at least a 2cm stump after surgery.
Surgery is the mainstay treatment of penile cancer. Chemotherapy regime includes 5-fluorouracil and cisplatin. Radiotherapy can be done for inguinal lymph nodes if lymph node dissection is not done.

Solution to Question 17:
Inguinal lymph node status is the most important prognostic indicator in penile carcinoma.
The prognosis for tumors confined to the penis is good with 5-year survival rates in excess of 80%. With nodal involvement, the 5-year survival rate falls to around 40%.

Solution to Question 1:
The most common site of ectopic testes is the superficial inguinal pouch.
Testes develop from the genital ridge in the retroperitoneum at 3 months of intrauterine life. They descend into the scrotum by 9 months of age due to differential abdominal growth, pull of the gubernaculum, and the effect of testosterone.
Cryptorchidism refers to the absence of one or both testes in the scrotal sac. The descent of the testis can be arrested in its usual path of descent (true undescended testis) or can migrate from the usual path of descent (ectopic testis).
The image below shows the possible sites of the testes in cryptorchidism:

A retractile testis can also lie in the inguinal canal and needs to be differentiated between an ectopic testes. It is present in the scrotum and occasionally moves into the inguinal canal.
An ectopic testis is treated with orchidopexy, while a retractile testis requires no intervention as it resolves spontaneously.
Solution to Question 2:
Orchidopexy is ideally performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age. Orchidopexy is done before 12 months of age to avoid the following complications:
Infertility

Solution to Question 3:
The tumor most likely to develop in this patient is seminoma.
The tumor that develops most commonly in undesceded testes is germ cell tumor in situ or intratubular germ cell tumor. It commonly progresses into seminomas.
In patients with a nonpalpable testicle, diagnostic laparoscopy is performed. If testis is still not visualised, the spermatic cord or testicular artery is traced at the deep inguinal ring to locate it.
If a blind ending spermatic cord is found instead, vanishing testis syndrome (or testicular regression syndrome) is suspected. It is the partial or total absence of testicular tissue often due to an ischemic event in foetal life.
The testis once found can be delivered into the scrotum, and an orchidopexy is performed.

Solution to Question 4:
In the first stage of a two-stage Stephens-Fowler approach, the testicular vessels are clipped.
Clipping of the testicular artery promotes neo vasculogenesis along the vas deferens. It does not result in ischemia of the testis due to the presence of collaterals from the cremasteric artery and the artery to the ductus deferens (deferential artery).
Several months later, after collaterals are established, the second stage is performed during which the testis and its new blood supply is mobilized into the scrotum.
Stephen-Fowler’s approach is done when an intra abdominal testes is located too far to reach the scrotum. Alternatively, Silbar’s orchiopexy may be done. In this procedure, microvascular anastomosis of the testicular vessels with internal illiac vessels is done after the testis is mobilised to the scrotum.
Solution to Question 5:
High investment of the tunica vaginalis is the most common cause of torsion of testis. It causes the testes to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell. This is the most common cause of testicular torsion in adolescents.
Bell clapper testes are typically bilateral. The image below shows the bell-clapper deformity of the testes:

Other abnormalities that cause torsion of the testes:
Inversion of the testis: The testis is rotated so that it lies transversely or upside down.
Pedicle between epididymis and body of testis: Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis by a pedicle allows torsion of the testis on the pedicle that connects the testis with the epididymis.
An appendix testis is a small vestigial appendage located on the upper pole of the testis. Twisting of the appendage causes testicular appendix torsion. In it, a classic blue dot sign is seen on the upper pole of the testis. It is seen as a hard tender nodule with a blue discoloration on the superior aspect of the testis. The patient usually presents with acute onset pain and swelling of the scrotum. On examination, the cremasteric reflex is lost, and the scrotum looks asymmetrical.

More than 80% of the testis can be salvaged if surgery is performed within 6 hours. If the testis is found to be necrosed on scrotal exploration, orchidectomy of the necrosed testis and orchidopexy of the contralateral testis is done.

Solution to Question 18:
Based on the gross and microscopic appearance of the specimen, the diagnosis is seminoma.
The gross specimen shows a well-circumscribed, pale, gray-white, fleshy, homogenous mass, with a lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathology shows uniform tumor cells with abundant clear cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, and large central nuclei. There is a sparse lymphocytic infiltrate. Classically, they have a fried egg appearance.
Other options:
Option B: Yolk-sac tumor has a yellowish-white, mucinous appearance. Histologically, they are typically composed of a lace-like (reticular) network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindled cells, which generally show less cytologic atypia than embryonal carcinoma. In approximately 50% of tumors, structures resembling endodermal sinuses (Schiller-Duval bodies) may be seen; these consist of a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells resembling primitive glomeruli.

Option C: Embryonal cell carcinoma appears variegated with foci of hemorrhage or necrosis. Histologically, the cells grow in alveolar or tubular patterns, sometimes with papillary folds. More undifferentiated lesions may display sheets of cells with cleft-like spaces. The neoplastic cells have an epithelial appearance, are large and anaplastic, and have hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli. The cell borders are usually indistinct, and there is considerable variation in cell and nuclear size and shape (pleomorphism). Mitotic figures and tumor giant cells are frequently seen.

Option D: Teratomas also have a variegated appearance but have cysts reflecting the multiplicity of tissue types. Histologically, collections of differentiated cells or organoid structures originating in all 3 germ layers can be seen. Elements may be mature (resembling various adult tissues) or immature (sharing histologic features with fetal or embryonic tissue).

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm. It is an extrarenal manifestation of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.

Solution to Question 14:
Bulbocavernosus reflex is the first reflex to return after the spinal shock has resolved.
It is elicited by squeezing the glans penis in males and applying pressure to the clitoris or pulling the Foleys catheter in females. Any of these will lead to anal sphincter contraction.
Spinal shock is a condition of transient physiologic reflex depression of spinal cord function (motor, sensory, tone, reflexes) below the level of injury. It usually results from a high-impact, direct trauma to the spinal cord. When the level of injury is above T6, it can result in hemodynamic changes such as hypotension and bradycardia (due to loss of sympathetic tone and unopposed parasympathetic function).
The resolution of spinal shock occurs over a period of days to months, when the areflexia slowly transitions to hyperreflexia and spasticity. Reflexes return sequentially rather than simultaneously. The resolution of the somatic component of spinal shock is classically signaled by the return of the bulbocavernosus reflex, a polysynaptic cutaneous spinal reflex (mediated by the conus medullaris) which is then followed by monosynaptic deep tendon reflexes (e.g. ankle jerk).

Solution to Question 15:
Steroids are not used in severe head injury, since they are associated with increased mortality. Initial management of raised intracranial pressure (ICP):
Airway protection
Positioning the head up 20–30° (reverse Trendelenburg positioning)
A bolus of mannitol up to 1 g/kg for free water diuresis (the effect is delayed by 20 min)
Hypertonic saline (3% or 5%)
Maintaining fluid and electrolyte balance
Seizure control
Sedation using a combination of opiates and barbiturates
Ventriculostomy and/or craniectomy may be needed for definitive decompression.
ICP normally varies between 4 and 14 mmHg. Sustained ICP levels above 25 mmHg can injure the brain. The goal of therapy in raised ICP is to maintain the ICP 20 - 25 mmHg.

The use of antiepileptics in late post-traumatic seizure (PTS) patients is recommended.
Post-traumatic seizures (PTS) are seizures that result from traumatic brain injury (TBI). They are classified into early and late. Early PTS occurs within 1 week and late PTS occurs after 1 week of trauma (Option C).
Early PTS are acute symptomatic events, attributed to a direct reaction to injury and hemorrhage. Risk factors for early PTS are:
Younger age (especially <5 years)
Moderate to severe head injury (measured by GCS)
Acute intracerebral hematoma
Subdural / Subarachnoid hemorrhage
Depressed skull fractures
Diffuse cerebral edema
History of alcohol abuse
Penetrating head injury
Late PTS usually occurs due to underlying permanent structural and physiologic changes within the brain. Patients with late PTS may develop post-traumatic epilepsy (PTE). It refers to recurrent and unprovoked PTS that occur at least 1 week after TBI. Risk factors for PTE are:
Early PTS
Severe head injury
Older age (especially >65 years)
Focal neurological deficit
Intracranial hemorrhage
Intracranial infection
Abnormalities on EEG
Alcohol-related head injury
Prolonged seizures (30 to 60 minutes) can cause secondary brain injury, not primary (Option B). Hence, it is imperative to control acute seizures as soon as possible.
The initiation of antiepileptics in early PTS patients is to prevent damage due to seizures themselves. It does not reduce the likelihood of developing PTE (Option D). For patients who develop late PTS, because of the high risk of seizure recurrence after the first episode of late PTS, the use of antiepileptic medication is recommended even after a single late seizure episode. The long-term sequelae of head injury are headache, raised ICP, impaired short-term memory, lack of concentration, emotional disinhibition, and depression.
Prophylaxis for PTS is indicated in patients at risk of early PTS, for 7 days and is stopped without tapering the dose if no seizures have occurred during this duration. Prophylaxis is not recommended for late PTS.

Pleomorphic adenoma, the most common benign salivary gland tumor, primarily affects the parotid gland, particularly its superficial lobe. It is also referred to as a mixed tumor due to its combination of epithelial and mesenchymal components. This tumor most commonly occurs in females around the age of 40.

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk:
Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. The anatomical landmarks include:
Conley's pointer is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
Posterior belly of digastric- The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle.
Mastoid process- Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.
Squamotympanic fissure is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
Styloid process- The facial nerve lies superficial to it.
Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:
Buccal branch lies in relation to the parotid gland
Marginal mandibular branch lies in relation to the facial vessels
Temporal branch

First-degree burns involve only the epidermis, are painful, but do not blister, protective functions of the skin are intact and heals without a scar.

The clinical scenario is suggestive of second-degree superficial burns. They usually heal with minimal scarring in 10–14 days unless they become infected.
Second-degree burns are divided into two types:
Superficial Dermal burns are erythematous and painful, blanch to touch, and often blister. They heal in 10–14 days.
Deep dermal burns involve the reticular dermis, appear more pale with erythmatous regions, do not blanch to touch, but remain painful to pinprick. They heal in 4–8 weeks.

Second-degree (partial thickness) burns involve the epidermis and some parts of the dermis (also known as partial-thickness burns). Further divided into:
Superficial second-degree burns - involves the upper part of the dermis (papillary) and shows pain, blisters, and severe swelling.
Deep second-degree burns - extends up to the reticular layer of the dermis and appears more pale and mottled, does not blanch to touch, but remains painful to pinprick.

Fourth-degree burns involve deep structures such as muscle and bone.

The zone of coagulation is the most severely burned portion and is typically in the center of the wound.
Peripheral to that is a zone of stasis, with variable degrees of vasoconstriction and resultant ischemia.
The last, outermost area of a burn is called the zone of hyperemia, which will heal with minimal or no scarring and is most like a superficial or first-degree burn. It is characterized by vasodilation from inflammation surrounding the burn wound.

Solution to Question 7:
Following irrigation of the burn site, topical application of calcium gluconate gel along with ECG monitoring is the most appropriate management.
Hydrofluoric acid is the strongest inorganic acid and it can cause liquefaction necrosis of deeper tissues (since the acid is highly lipophilic). Pain out of proportion to physical examination is a hallmark finding in HF burns. Systemic absorption of fluoride ions can result in intravascular chelation of calcium causing hypocalcemia.
Depletion of calcium causes inhibition of the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, leading to hyperkalemia and subsequent life-threatening arrhythmias. Therefore ECG monitoring is imperative. ECG abnormalities that can occur include prolonged QTc (from hypocalcemia) and QRS widening (from hyperkalemia).
Following copious irrigation of the burn site with water, the mainstay of treatment is with topical application of calcium gluconate gel. If the pain does not subside, or if systemic signs ensue, an intraarterial injection of calcium gluconate can be given in the affected extremity.

Solution to Question 1:
Neutrophil peak is seen on day 2 of the inflammatory phase of wound healing.
Wound healing has three phases: The inflammatory phase, proliferative phase, and maturation phase. The inflammatory phase lasts 2-3 days.

Solution to Question 2:
The given image shows granulation tissue formed during the proliferative stage of wound healing. Fibroblasts are the predominant cell during the proliferative stage.
Fibroblasts are specialized cells that differentiate from resting mesenchymal cells into connective tissue. The primary function of fibroblasts is to synthesize collagen.
The proliferative stage of wound healing is characterized by the formation of granulation tissue, which consists of a capillary bed, fibroblasts, macrophages, and a loose arrangement of collagen, fibronectin, and hyaluronic acid.

Solution to Question 4:
Dietary deficiency of vitamin C (scurvy) results in poorly formed collagen and affects the early matrix scaffolding.
Type I and Type III collagens are both present in the extracellular matrix of normal skin (in an 8:1 ratio). However, during the proliferative phase of wound healing, the dominant collagen that is laid is Type III. This stage is also known as early matrix scaffolding. Type III collagen is gradually replaced by type I collagen (during the final remodeling phase) until a ratio (type I: type III) of 4:1 is achieved.

All the factors listed impair wound healing, but local infection is the most common underlying cause of non-healing surgical incisions.

Solution to Question 6:
While all of the given options are inhibited by steroids, the major effect of steroids is to inhibit the initial inflammatory phase of wound healing (angiogenesis, neutrophil and macrophage migration, and fibroblast proliferation) and the release of lysosomal enzymes.
The stronger the anti-inflammatory effect of the steroid compound used, the greater the inhibitory effect on wound healing. Steroids used after the first 3 to 4 days post-injury do not affect wound healing as severely as when they are used in the immediate postoperative period.
In addition to inhibiting collagen synthesis, steroids also inhibit epithelialization and contraction and contribute to increased rates of wound infection, regardless of the time of administration.
Steroid delayed healing of cutaneous wounds can be stimulated to epithelialize by topical application of vitamin A.
Solution to Question 7:
Everted edge around a chronic wound is a sign of malignant transformation.
The majority of wounds that have not healed in 3 months are considered chronic and are prone to malignant changes. Malignant wounds are differentiated clinically from non-malignant wounds by the presence of overturned edges. Biopsy of the wound edges should be performed to rule out malignancy.
Malignant transformation can occur in any long-standing wound. The image shows a Marjolin's ulcer with everted edges. It is squamous cell carcinoma that develops on a long-standing burn.

Solution to Question 8:
Contaminated wounds older than 6 hours should be managed with delayed primary closure.
The wound is cleaned, debrided, and left open for a few days. This allows soft tissues to drain and also ensures no infection is present before surgical closure can be done.
Wound closure is categorized into primary, secondary, or tertiary:
Primary closure is done for clean wounds with minimal tissue loss that are amenable to approximation of wound edges. Healing occurs by primary intention. Primary closure is ideally performed within 6 to 8 hrs of trauma, but wounds in vascular areas (e.g. face) may be delayed to up to 24 hours after trauma.
Secondary closure allows healing by secondary intention. The wound is left open to heal largely by the formation of granulation tissue and contraction. These wounds often have significant tissue loss precluding tension-free approximation of edges, with devitalized edges. Wound dressings are changed daily to aid in the formation of granulation tissue and subsequent contraction.
Tertiary closure, also known as delayed primary closure, results in a combination of healing by primary and secondary intention. The wound is thoroughly irrigated, debrided, and left open for 2 to 5 days before surgical closure. It is used for wounds that are grossly contaminated without significant tissue loss.
Solution to Question 9:
The given image shows complete skin loss that involves muscles and shows exposed bone indicating a stage 4 pressure sore.
Pressure sores are skin or soft tissue injuries that occur due to prolonged pressure over specific areas of the body. An external pressure of >30 mmHg leads to the formation of pressure sores.
The common sites of pressure sores in decreasing frequency are the ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral followed by medial), and occiput.
Pressure sores can be prevented with good skincare, the use of air-fluidized beds, special pressure-dispersion cushions, or foams. Repositioning the patient every two hours can lessen the pressure on the area.
Ulcers of stages 1 and 2 often do not require operative measures. They are managed with regular wound cleaning and dressing with a good antibiotic cover.
Stage 3 and 4 ulcers are adequately debrided, and vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) is used to promote the growth of granulation tissue required for surgical closure. Large skin flaps that have muscle with sensory innervation are best for reconstruction.

Preoperative management involves adequate debridement, and the use of vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) to provide a suitable wound for surgical closure. Alginates, foams, hydrocolloids, hydrogels are other options that are available.
The aim of surgery is to fill the dead space and to provide durable sensate skin. Large skin flaps that include muscle are best and, occasionally, an intact sensory innervated area can be included (e.g. extensor fascia lata flap with the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh).
Nutritional optimization with high caloric and protein diet should be done to establish a positive nitrogen balance. Frequent changes in position and air mattresses can also help in preventing further sores.

Solution to Question 13:
During the first week, a surgical wound has minimal inherent strength because the dermal edges are held together solely by a hemostatic plug and sutures.
During the second postoperative week, fibroblasts proliferate rapidly and begin to produce type I collagen in addition to type III. The strength of the wound is still limited to less than 10% of its final strength. By week 6, the concentration of strong collagen fibers begins to resemble that of intact skin.
As the collagen matures and becomes denser, the scar becomes almost acellular as the fibroblasts and blood vessels reduce.The disorganized collagen fibers become aligned along stress lines with their strength being in their weave rather than in their amount.
Most of these changes occur over the first three months but a scar will continue to mature for 1 to 2 years. Tensile strength will continue to increase but would not be expected to exceed 60–80% of that of normal skin.

Surgical excision in combination with adjuvant therapy is advised to patients with refractory keloids.
The adjuvant therapy usually includes radiation.The risk of malignancy attributable to keloid radiation therapy is minimal
Treatment of keloids :
First-line treatments include silicones in combination with pressure therapy and intralesional corticosteroid injections.
Intralesional 5-fluorouracil, bleomycin, and verapamil should be used in accordance with established treatment protocols.
Refractory cases after 12 months of therapy should be considered for surgical excision in combination with adjuvant therapy.
Excision alone results in a high recurrence rate of 50% to 100% and enlargement of the keloid.
Immediate postoperative electron beam irradiation or brachytherapy with iridium-192 reduces recurrence rates. The risk of malignancy attributable to keloid radiation therapy is minimal.
An additional new invasive treatment modality is internal cryotherapy, in which a metal rod is introduced into the keloid and the subsequent extreme cooling leads to tissue necrosis.

The given image shows a meshed, split-thickness skin graft. Split grafts are meshed to expand the surface area that can be covered but it does not improve the cosmetic appearance.
Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).
Less dermis also translates into a better chance of graft survival. Thin split grafts have a low primary contraction, high secondary contraction, and high reliability of graft take. However, they tend to heal with abnormal pigmentation and poor durability.

Solution to Question 10:
The image shows a typical example of a Z Plasty.
It is a type of transposition flap that incorporates qualities of both advancement and rotation flaps. Z plasty is used for the lengthening of linear scars. It is best used in releasing simple contractures.
Usually, all the limbs are of equal length and ideally, the angle between them is 60°. Two triangular flaps are raised. Theoretically, a 60-degree angle flap will result in a 75% increase in the length of the scar and a 90-degree reorientation of central wound.
Angles smaller than 60 degrees are easier to transpose but result in less lengthening and realignment of the scar to less than 90 degrees. Angles larger than 60 degrees should be avoided because the force required to transpose the flaps increases markedly, making the closure of the wound difficult.
Relative contraindications to Z-plasty include patients with keloids and hypertrophic scarring tendencies.

Solution to Question 11:
The Limberg flap is a type of random flap and the safe and reliable length:width ratio for the random flap 3:1.
Random pattern flaps have a blood supply based on small, unnamed blood vessels in the dermal-subdermal plexus, as opposed to the discrete, well described, directional vessels of axial
pattern flaps. As random flaps have a variable blood supply, they need an adequate base (width) to survive.
The rhomboid (Limberg) flap involves creating a skin flap with two opposing angles of 60° and 120° at the corners, forming a rhomboid shape positioned directly next to the defect. The design allows the flap to be rotated into the defect, with the donor site closed primarily, ensuring minimal distortion to the surrounding tissues. This method is especially useful in areas like the gluteal region, where complex closure techniques help achieve optimal results.

The given image showing only skin and fat moved to the chest is suggestive of a deep inferior epigastric artery perforator flap (DIEP), based on the deep inferior epigastric artery.
DIEP is a variant of TRAM flap and free flap where only the skin and fat are moved to the chest. A microvascular technique is used in which no muscle is taken and the perforating vessels are dissected out.
As the muscle is spared in DIEP, there is a reduced risk of abdominal wall weakness and its associated complications.

Solution to Question 17:
A horizontal incision should be taken as the relaxed skin tension lines (Borge's lines) at the bridge of the nose are horizontal.
Aligning a surgical incision or excision with skin tension lines results in minimal tension across the closure of the defect. This leads to optimal scar formation and minimizes wound contraction.
Skin tension lines reflect internal tension within the skin and are produced by the parallel alignment of connective tissue of the dermis. Several different skin tension lines have been described. Borge's lines which are also called relaxed skin tension lines are most useful to guide surgical incision. These are often confused with Langer's lines.
Langer's lines, also called cleavage lines are topological lines drawn based on the shape of wounds on cadavers. These were not intended as a guide for surgical incisions and they do not always correspond to the best orientation of skin tension and often run perpendicular to skin folds. On the face, these two sets of lines often run at right angles to one another.

The given clinical picture is suggestive of infantile hemangioma. Only monitoring of the lesion is required as in 50% of cases, complete involution is seen by 5 years of age.
Hemangioma growth frequently peaks before the first year, and then the lesions enter the involuting phase. The involution phase begins in 50% of children by 5 years of age and in 70% by 7 years of age. It continues until 10 years of age.
Indications for immediate treatment are complications such as ulceration or those pertaining to the location of the mass (e.g. visual issues due to large hemangioma over eyelid).
Treatment options include:
Beta blockers - oral propranolol
Steroids - intralesional triamcinolone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids
Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine - for steroid-resistant lesions
Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser
