Solution to Question 2:
The given CT shows an intralobar pulmonary sequestration of the left lung. The thoracic aorta commonly supplies the sequestered lobe of the lung.
Pulmonary sequestration is an area of embryonic lung tissue, separate from the lung. It receives blood supply from an anomalous systemic artery from the aorta. It is of two types:
Extralobar sequestration occurs primarily on the left side and blood supply is usually from the thoracic or upper abdominal aorta
Intralobar sequestration occurs in the lower lobes predominantly (>95%). It is equally distributed between the right and left lower lobe and blood supply is from the descending thoracic
aorta, venous drainage via pulmonary veins
Treatment involves resection of the pulmonary sequestration.
Solution to Question 3:
Massive hemoptysis is defined as the expectoration of over 600 mL of blood within a 24-hour period. Common causes include tuberculosis, bronchiectasis, and cancer. It is a medical emergency.
Any hemoptysis that can cause airway compromise or lead to hemodynamic collapse is called massive hemoptysis. This includes blood loss of >600mL/24h or >150ml/h which can flood the anatomical dead space of the lung.
Bleeding can either be from the bronchial artery circulation (most common) or from the pulmonary artery circulation. Bleeding from cavitary lesions is due to pulmonary artery erosion.
The chest X-ray is the first investigation followed by rigid or flexible bronchoscopy.
The cause of death in massive hemoptysis is usually due to asphyxiation (rather than blood loss itself). This is why airway stabilization by intubating into the non-bleeding lung is the priority. After ventilation is achieved, the bleeding site should be identified using bronchoscopy. Bleeding is controlled by laser, bronchial occlusion, or arterial embolization. Surgical resection of the involved area is also done in some cases.
Indications for urgent surgical intervention for massive hemoptysis:
Presence of a fungus ba
Presence of a lung abscess
Presence of significant cavitary disease
Failure to control the bleeding.
Solution to Question 4:
The aneurysm of the pulmonary artery within the tuberculous cavity is called Rasmussen’s aneurysm.
Rasmussen's aneurysm is an inflammatory pseudo-aneurysmal dilatation. This occurs during the healing of the tuberculous cavity. There is a progressive weakening of the arterial wall, in which both the tunica adventitia and media are replaced by granulation tissue. This is gradually replaced by fibrin resulting in thinning of the arterial wall leading to pseudoaneurysm formation.
Rupture of Rasmussen's aneurysm can cause massive hemoptysis. CT angiography plays an important role in locating the aneurysm.
Most cases of massive hemoptysis arise from the bronchial arterial tree because of high pressure within bronchial arteries. Even when a pulmonary aneurysm is present, the actual bleeding may be from the bronchial artery, rather than from the pulmonary artery itself.
Solution to Question 5:
The left side is most likely to be the bleeding side in this patient. Hence, the patient should be placed in the left lateral decubitus position to prevent aspiration into the unaffected lung. Also, a CT scan is not indicated as he is hemodynamically unstable.
Treatment priorities in the management of massive hemoptysis:
First priorities are to maintain the airway, optimize oxygenation and stabilize the hemodynamic status by administering IV fluids.
Chest X-ray is the first investigation of choice. CT scan is done only in hemodynamically stable patients.
If the bleeding side is known, the patient should be placed in a lateral decubitus position, with the bleeding side down to prevent aspiration into the unaffected lung and given supplementa oxygen.
If large-volume bleeding continues or the airway is compromised, the patient should be intubated and undergo emergency bronchoscopy.
The bleeding site is localized using flexible/rigid bronchoscopy.
Control the hemorrhage:
Endobronchially with Nd: YAG laser or bronchial occlusion
Endovascularly with bronchial and/or pulmonary artery embolization
Electrocauterization
Surgically with resection of the involved lobe
The cause of the hemoptysis must be determined to definitively prevent a recurrence.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of primary pneumothorax. The next step would be to discharge and follow up in 2-4 weeks as the size is <2cm.
Pneumothorax is the abnormal accumulation of air in the pleural space. It can be primary or secondary.
Primary pneumothorax can occur spontaneously due to rupture of the apical blebs. Risk factors include:
Males > Females
Young, tall, and thin individuals
Family history
Smoking
It resolves spontaneously hence just follow-up is usually needed in most cases. Secondary pneumothorax occurs due to some underlying pathology. Risk factors include:
Age> 50 years
Smoking
COPD
Asthma
Cystic fibrosis
Infection (pneumonia, abscess, and tuberculosis)
Interstitial lung disease
Connective tissue disease
Procedures (subclavian lines, thoracentesis, bronchoscopy, and mechanical ventilation)
Blunt trauma
Patients with pneumothorax present with acute dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. A physical examination will reveal:
An enlarged hemithorax
Decreased chest movements
Hyper-resonance on percussion
Absent vocal fremitus
Diminished breath sounds
Diagnosis is made by chest X-ray (best initial test), CT scan, or USG. Management of pneumothorax:
Primary pneumothorax
<2 cm size: Discharge and follow-up in 2-4 weeks
>2 cm size and/or breathless: Aspirate with 16 G cannula  If fails, place a chest drain of size 8-14 Fr
Secondary pneumothorax
<1 cm size: High-flow oxygen with observation for 24 hours

Solution to Question 8:
The ultrasound diagnosis of pneumothorax depends on the presence of barcode sign, absence of the sliding lung and absence of comet-tail artifacts that are seen in relation to a normal
lung–pleural interface.
Normally, lung sliding corresponds to the to-and-fro movement of the visceral pleura on the parietal pleura that occurs with respiration. It is a dynamic sign and can be identified on ultrasound as horizontal movement along the pleural line.
In pneumothorax, the air separates visceral and parietal pleura and prevents visualization of visceral pleura. Hence lung sliding is absent and typical to and fro movement and shimmering of the pleural lines will not be present.
Comet tail artifacts are seen in the normal lungs due to the acoustic impedance differences between water and air, whereas it is absent in pneumothorax.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The first line of management in tension pneumothorax is to insert a wide-bore needle in the 5th intercostal space just anterior to the midaxillary line.
Pneumothorax is the abnormal accumulation of air in the pleural space. Tension pneumothorax develops when air enters the pleural space through a point that acts as a one-way valve. More and more air enters with every breath without any way for the air to escape. This is a medical emergency where the patient can quickly deteriorate.
A patient with pneumothorax presents with acute dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. A physical examination will reveal:
An enlarged hemithorax
Decreased chest movements
Hyper-resonance on percussion
Absent vocal fremitus
Diminished breath sounds
In addition to the above findings, a tension pneumothorax would also have the following:
Deviation of trachea to the opposite side
Distended neck vein
Cyanosis
Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise:
Hypotension
Tachycardia
Low O2 saturation
Loss of consciousness
A diagnosis of tension pneumothorax is usually made based on the clinical findings. If the tension in the pleural cavity is not relieved, the patient can die due to hemodynamic collapse. Hence, treatment should never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation.
The management of tension pneumothorax is to convert a tension pneumothorax into a simple pneumothorax. This can be done by rapid decompression using a wide-bore cannula on the affected side, followed by the insertion of a chest tube for definitive management.
The safest site for insertion of a drain is in the triangle (Triangle of safety) that lies:
Anterior to the mid-axillary line
Above the level of the nipple
Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle

Note:
If immediate management is asked, the answer will be to insert a wide-bore needle in the 5th intercostal space in the midaxillary line.
If definitive management is asked, the answer will be to insert an intercostal tube in the triangle of safety.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of open pneumothorax. Initial management, in this case, is to apply occlusive dressing taped on the 3 sides.
Open pneumothorax is due to a large open defect in the chest, making intrathoracic pressure equal to atmospheric pressure. In this defect, the air is preferentially drawn through the defect, rather than through the trachea. Air gets accumulated causing pneumothorax leading to hypoventilation and hypoxia. It acts as a sucking chest wound. Sucking sound during inspiration is characteristic.
It is managed initially with the application of a sterile occlusive dressing tapped on the 3 sides. Then a chest tube is inserted at a different site, away from the wound.

Empyema thoracis is an infection of the pleural space. It commonly progresses from an acute phase with thin fluid that can be drained completely with a chest tube or small-bore catheter to a more turbid and thick fluid that might loculate. It is an exudative effusion. It can be caused due to:
Underlying infection of the lung (pneumonia or abscess)
Complication after chest surgery
Infected hemothorax
Complication of Pleural effusion
Trauma (esophageal perforation)
Osteomyelitis of ribs
An empyema thoracis on chest x-ray can mimic a pleural effusion or a lung abscess.
The procedure VATS (Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery) is used in the debridement of empyema. At the end of the procedure, chest drains are placed for dependent drainage.
If VATS fails to re-expand the lung after drainage, a more radical procedure (decortication) may be done.

Malignancies

The patient is usually positioned with the diseased side up in a lateral decubitus position.

Left internal mammary artery > Radial artery > long saphenous vein represents the correct order of graft patency in a patient undergoing CABG procedure.
Venous grafts:
The long saphenous vein is the most common vein used as a conduit as it is straightforward to harvest, provides good length, and is easy to handle.
The ten-year patency rate for long saphenous vein grafts is reported to be 50–60 percent. Arterial grafts:
The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) or internal thoracic artery has become the conduit of choice for the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. Long patency rates of >98 percent have been reported.

The Stanford classification is used to separate aortic dissections into those that need surgical repair, and those that usually require only medical management. The Stanford classification divides dissections by the most proximal involvement.
Type A is when ascending aorta and arch are affected. It requires urgent surgical management and may result in:
Coronary artery occlusion
Aortic incompetence
Rupture into the pericardial sac with resulting cardiac tamponade
Type B begins beyond brachiocephalic vessels and dissection commences distal to the left subclavian artery affecting only the descending aorta. Medical management with blood pressure control is the preferred choice of treatment.
The DeBakey classification divides dissections into:
Type I: involves ascending and descending aorta (= Stanford A)
Type II: involves ascending aorta only (= Stanford A)
Type III: involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of the left subclavian artery (= Stanford B)

Most cases of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) are unilateral. It is bilateral in only 30% of the individuals.
DVT refers to thrombosis of the deep venous system. Caused by:
Postoperative thrombosis (most common cause)

Mose's sign: Gentle squeezing of the lower part of the calf from side to side is painful.
Neuhof's sign: Thickening and deep tenderness seen on deep palpation of the calf muscles.
Sometimes, the thrombus may get dislodged and present as pulmonary thromboembolism (option D) with features of dyspnoea, tachypnoea, and chest pain.
Clinical features are unreliable for making a definitive diagnosis (option A), and a venous Doppler is the best modality for confirming DVT. It reveals a non-compressible dilated vein. The likelihood of pulmonary embolism can be predicted using modified Wells criteria.

months. Vena cava filters are used in patients with bleeding risks (like hemophilia).

The patient is having phlegmasia alba dolens also known milk leg or white leg. It is due to ileofemoral deep vein thrombosis.
It is usually seen in pregnant women and in individuals at risk of developing deep vein thrombosis. They typically present with painful, oedematous, and pale lower limb that blanches to touch. The lack of cyanosis differentiates this entity from phlegmasia cerulea dolens.
In phlegmasia alba dolens, the thrombosis involves only major deep venous channels of the extremity, thus sparing collateral veins. The venous drainage is decreased but still present.

In phlegmasia cerulea dolens, the thrombosis extends to collateral veins, resulting in severe venous congestion with massive fluid sequestration and more significant edema.
Both phlegmasia cerulea dolens and phlegmasia alba dolens results from acute massive deep vein thrombosis and can be complicated by venous gangrene.
Edema of pregnancy does not present with pain in the lower limbs but edema due to pressure exerted by the gravid uterus on the iliac veins.
Solution to Question 6:
Heparin, especially low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is more effective for prophylaxis of DVT in patients who have undergone major surgeries where early ambulation is not possible.
The choice of prophylaxis depends on the type of surgery, trauma, and duration of postoperative immobilisation. Major trauma, abdominal and orthopaedic surgeries warrant a longer duration of postoperative immobilisation. So, the pharmacological method is preferred in these situations.
Mechanical methods are advised in patients who are expected to be up and walking within 24 to 48 hours such as after minor trauma. The simplest method is for the patient to ambulate. The activation of the calf pump mechanism is an effective means of prophylaxis.
Additionally, compression stockings are advised. It can reduce the risk of DVT by exerting graduated pressure on the leg, with the pressure being greatest at the ankle.
Advantages of LMWH over unfractionated heparin:
LMWH has a longer plasma half-life and significantly higher bioavailability.
The consistent bioavailability and clearance of LMWH do not require monitoring of aPTT or anti-factor Xa activity.
Dosing is merely based on the patient’s weight.
There is a more predictable anticoagulant response than with unfractionated heparin.
LMWH inhibits factor Xa and not IIa activity, with the ratio of anti-factor Xa to anti-factor IIa activity ranging from 1:1 to 4:1.

Varicose veins are defined as dilated, usually tortuous, subcutaneous veins >3 mm in diameter measured in the upright position with demonstrable reflux.
Important risk factors for varicose veins are:
Sex – Females > Males

Family history
Body mass and height: Increasing BMI (obesity) and height are associated with a high prevalence of varicose veins.
There is inconclusive evidence regarding the increased prevalence of varicose veins in smokers, patients who suffer constipation, and occupations that involve prolonged standing.
Primary varicose veins are due to genetic or developmental defects in the vein wall that causes diminished elasticity and valvular incompetence.
Secondary varicose veins arise from destruction or dysfunction of valves caused by trauma, DVT, AV fistula, non-traumatic proximal venous obstruction (pregnancy, pelvic tumor).

Corona phlebectatica are fan-shaped patterns of small intradermal veins on the medial or lateral aspects of the ankle or foot. It is also called ankle flare or malleolar flare. It is an early sign of advanced venous disease.

Saphenofemoral flush ligation is done in Trendelenburg’s procedure.

Procedure:
An oblique groin incision is made at the level of and lateral to the pubic tubercle. The great saphenous vein is identified and dissected to the saphenofemoral junction.

The superficial inferior epigastric vein and superficial circumflex iliac vein laterally
The deep and superficial external pudendal veins medially
More distally the anterolateral and posteromedial thigh veins
A flush saphenofemoral junction ligation is then performed and the great saphenous vein retrogradely stripped to the knee. Solution to Question 26:
The gradual filling of veins from below upwards indicates the perforator incompetence. Brodie Trendelenberg test is performed to test for the incompetence of the saphenofemoral valve and the communicating system.
Trendelenburg’s test - Lay the patient down and elevate the leg. Empty the vessels and tie a tourniquet below the SFJ. Ask the patient to stand up:
Trendelenburg’s test part ll - Here the tourniquet is not released. A gradual filling from below to upwards indicates perforator incompetence.
Trendelenburg’s test part l - Here the tourniquet is released. A rapid filling from above shows the saphenofemoral incompetence.
Morrisey’s cough impulse: the patient is asked to cough. A cough impulse at the saphenofemoral junction indicates SFJ incompetence.
Schwartz test: If a thrill is felt at SFJ on tapping over the incompetent vein, indicates SFJ incompetence.
Modified Perthes test: A tourniquet is tied below SFJ and the patient is asked to walk. An increase in pain and prominence of dilated veins indicate DVT.
Fegan’s method - Mark the places of excessive bulges within the varicosities. Ask the patient to lie down and empty the varicose vessels. Palpate along the marked area to look for gaps and pits in the deep fascia, which indicates perforator incompetence.

Solution to Question 1:
Lymphedema is the most probable cause of long-standing non-pitting edema in the limbs.
Lymphedema is the abnormal accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the interstitial spaces of the tissues.
Lymphedema can be primary or secondary. Primary lymphedema includes:
Lymphedema congenita (0-2 years): more common in males, involves multiple limbs, face, and genitalia. It can be familial or sporadic. The familial type is called Nonne Milroy syndrome.
Lymphedema praecox (2-35 years): more common in females, the most common type of primary lymphedema with a peak incidence in puberty. It can be familial or sporadic. The familial type is called Meig's disease.
Lymphedema tarda (>35 years): Rare and uncommon.
Secondary lymphedema is more common than primary and is the most common cause of lymphedema overall. Causes include lymph node dissection (axillary or inguinal),
post-mastectomy, postoperative radiotherapy, obesity, varicose vein surgery, and trauma.
Complications of lymphedema include infections, skin changes, recurent cellulitis, non-healing ulcers, and lymphangiosarcoma.
Treatment mostly includes patient education and nonsurgical interventions, which include limb elevation, and external compressive garments. When the above methods fail, surgery can be
considered.

Direct contrast lymphangiography is done by dissecting the lymphatic vasculature through an incision on the dorsum of the foot and injecting contrast.
Direct contrast lymphangiography is an invasive study done to visualise the lymphatic system. It involves exposure and cannulation of lymphatics and slow injection of contrast medium such

Solution to Question 6:
Marjolin's ulcers are unlikely to develop in patients with chronic lymphedema.
Marjolin’s ulcers are malignant ulcers that develop over chronic scars, most commonly from burns. Marjolin's ulcer may also develop in chronic long standing venous ulcers but are not seen in chronic lymphedema.
Initially, the lymphedema is soft and pits on the pressure but with time the skin becomes thickened and non-pitting due to fibrosis, dermal thickening, and hyperkeratosis.
Frequent episodes of lymphangitis and cellulitis may occur. This is due to loss of local immune defense mechanisms. Chronic eczema, the fungal infection of skin and nails, fissuring, verrucae, and papillae (warts) are frequently seen in advanced disease.
Rarely malignancy (lymphangiosarcoma or angiosarcoma) may occur in chronic lymphedema. This neoplastic transformation of blood vessels and lymphatics is called Stewart-Treves syndrome.
Solution to Question 7:
Anterior compartment is the most common site of lymphoma in the mediastinum. Other sites include the middle compartment and hilar nodes.
Primary mediastinal lymphoma is an uncommon type of lymphoma. Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL), primary mediastinal B-cell lymphoma (PMBCL), and T-lymphoblastic lymphoma are the most common primary mediastinal lymphomas. In about 50% of patients who have both Hodgkin’s and Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma, the mediastinum may be the primary site.
Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome refers to symptoms produced by the obstruction of blood flow through the SVC by the enlarging mediastinal mass, resulting in symptoms of dyspnea, facial and upper-extremity edema, cough, chest pain, and dysphagia.
Video-assisted thoracoscopy (VATS) is used to obtain a biopsy of the mediastinal mass for confirmation and diagnosis.
Chemotherapy with six cycles of R-CHOP regimen is preferred. Rituximab is a chimeric monoclonal anti-CD20 antibody and has become a standard component of treating all B-cell lymphoma histologies that express CD20.
Note: Thymoma is the most common mediastinal tumor in adults (overall).

The given image depicts a lymphangioma, also known as cystic hygroma. They are brilliantly transilluminant.
Lymphangiomas are congenital benign tumors of the lymphatic system. They are the isolated cystic mass of lymphatic tissue that has the ability to produce lymph. Over time the tumor enlarges due to the accumulation of lymph within the cyst.
Types of lymphangiomas:
Simple or capillary lymphangioma: They occur subcutaneously in the head, neck, and axilla. They may also occur within the internal organs and connective tissues in the thoracic and abdominal cavities.
Cavernous lymphangioma or cystic hygroma: They also occur in the neck or axilla. Rarely they may occur in retroperitoneum.
Treatment includes surgical excision of the tumor and image-guided sclerotherapy.
If there is any residual lymphatic malformation after the treatment, then a conservative excision or unroofing of the cyst is done. It may be combined with sclerosing therapy or repeated partial excisions.
Note: The terms lymphangioma and cystic hygromas are older terms. They are now called lymphatic malformations.

Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare tumor that develops as a complication of long-standing lymph- edema.

Clinically, the patients present with acute worsening of the edema and appearance of subcutaneous nodules that have a propensity toward hemorrhage and ulceration.
The tumor can be treated, like other sarcomas, with preoperative chemotherapy and radiation followed by surgical excision, which usually may take the form of radical amputation. Overall, the prognosis is very poor.
Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical vignette and the image are suggestive of post-mastectomy lymphedema involving the upper limb.
Lymphoedema occurs when interstitial fluid accumulates due to defective lymphatic drainage. It is a common complication of breast cancer treatment involving axillary lymph node
dissection and radiotherapy. Sentinel lymph node dissection (SLND) reduces the risk of
lymphedema significantly.
Clinical signs and symptoms are observed in the ipsilateral arm. A significant increase in the limb size due to swelling is seen. Other symptoms are heaviness, tightness, numbness, tingling, limb fatigue, and reduced limb mobility.
Diagnosis is predominantly based on the clinical swelling of the arm. The girth of the affected arm >2 centimeters than the normal limb, a 200-mL or more increase in limb volume, or a 5% or greater limb volume change are other diagnostic criteria.
Management:
Limb elevation, elastic arm stockings, and pneumatic compression devices can help reduce swelling.
Dry skin can be seen due to fluid accumulation, which can lead to cellulitis/skin infections. Using a low pH water-based moisturizer is helpful.
Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) by a therapist followed by simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) by the patient daily aids interstitial fluid evacuation.
Benzpyrones and flavonoids are some naturally occurring substances that may be of use to treat lymphedema.
Surgical options are lymphaticovenular anastomosis, liposuction, and debulking. Other options:
Option B: Stewart-Treves syndrome refers to lymphangiosarcoma seen in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy (more than 10 years). They present as single/multiple
bluish-red skin and subcutaneous nodules. They can ulcerate and hemorrhage.
Option C: Axillary venous thrombosis or Paget-Schrotter disease is seen in patients doing rigorous exercise and in weightlifters. The subclavian vein is compressed at the thoracic outlet. Painful swelling of the arm is observed.
Option D: Cellulitis usually presents with an ulcer and the skin is erythematous, swollen, and painful. Fever, chills, and rigor follow.
Solution to Question 11:
Diuretics and Homan’s procedure are not a part of DLT, and are a part of drug therapy and surgical management.
Decongestive lymphoedema therapy (DLT) is the currently used method for controlling swelling in lymphoedema. It consists of 2 phases: intensive and maintenance.
Intensive phase includes:
Skin care: Prevent drying of skin and exposure to the sun, avoid venipuncture from the affected limb.
Limb elevation
Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) - Proximal massage along lymphatic channels.
Compression therapy: Multilayer lymphoedema bandaging (MLLB), Pneumatic lymphoedema stockings, Graded compression stockings (100% in the ankle/foot, 70% in the knee, 50% in mid-thigh, and 40% in the groin).
Exercise: Slow rhythmic isotonic movements are beneficial, while vigorous, anaerobic isometric exercises are to be avoided.
Standard MLLB is only done if ABPI is  0.8. It is contraindicated if ABPI is < 0.5. Maintenance phase includes:
Simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) - It is a simple massage technique done by the patient.
Pain relief

Kinmonth procedure is a bypass surgery done for lymphoedema not a limb reduction surgery.
Surgical management of lymphoedema is divided into bypass procedures, liposuction, and limb reduction procedures.
Bypass procedures include:
Neilubowicz procedure - anastomosing lymph nodes to the veins.
Kinmonth procedure - using ileal mucosal patch.
Limb reduction procedures include:
Sistrunk procedure - A wedge of skin and subcutaneous tissue is excised and the wound closed primarily. This is the most commonly carried out procedure to reduce the girth of the thigh.
Homan’s procedure - Skin flaps are raised, and then subcutaneous tissue is excised from beneath the flaps.
Thompson’s procedure - Modification of Homan’s procedure.
Charles procedure - Excision of all of the skin and subcutaneous tissues down to the deep fascia, with coverage using split-skin grafts.

SCC is the second most common skin cancer, while BCC is the most common skin cancer. Variants of SCC in-situ include:
Bowen's disease

SCC initially presents as smooth nodular, verrucous, papillomatous lesions. These lesions then ulcerate and form a characteristic, everted edge, surrounded by inflamed, indurated skin.
Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Other modalities of treatment include:

Solution to Question 4:
Broder's staging for SCC is based on histological grading. Depth or size of the tumor and lymph node involvement are not included in Broder's staging.
A skin biopsy is mandatory in all patients with suspected squamous cell carcinoma. Mohs micrographic surgery is indicated in patients with aggressive and high-risk SCC.

Perineural invasion

Lesions on the ear

Treatment of choice is an excisional procedure with 4 mm margins.
Option A: Actinic keratoses consist of hyperkeratotic erythematous papules and patches on the sun-exposed skin. They arise in middle-aged to older adults and have some potential for malignant transformation.

It initially presents with a red- dened□ area that progresses to thickened plaques and may vary from small lesions (<1 cm) to large areas. When it is confined to the glans penis or vulva, Bowen disease is sometimes referred to as Erythroplasia of Queyrat.

Solution to Question 8:
The given history with the image showing an ulcer over the face with pearly, rolled-out borders points to a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma.
Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is an epithelial tumor arising from basal cells. It is the most common type of skin cancer most commonly seen over the face, above the line joining corner of the mouth, and lobule of the ear. Risk factors for BCC include ultraviolet radiation (strongest risk factor), age 40-80 years with excessive sun exposure, light-skinned people, and exposure to arsenic compounds, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and infrared light. It is more common in males than females. It is also associated with syndromes such as xeroderma pigmentosum and Gorlin's syndrome.
Features of BCC include:
Pearly nodule with rolled border
Tortuous telangiectatic vessels
Surface which can get ulcerated with raised and beaded edge, often with a central depression or umbilicatio
Bleeding on minor trauma
BCC has various subtypes such as nodular (most common type), pigmented, nodulocystic, morphoeic, infiltrative, and fibroepithelioma of Pinkus.
It is locally aggressive and can erode the bone or facial sinuses. It rarely metastasizes via lymph nodes.
The occasional presence of melanin in the nodular variant of BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to confusion with melanoma.
Depending upon the type of the lesion, a shave, punch or excisional biopsy may be employed for diagnosis. X-ray or CT may be needed if there is a local invasion. Histology shows peripheral palisading of cells.
Treatment:
Surgical: Wide excision (4-6 mm clearance) with a skin graft or flap or primary suturing
Mohs' surgery for BCC close to the eyes, nose, or ear to preserve more tissue.
Non-surgical: Radiotherapy, vismodegib and sonedegib. Other options:
Option A: Dermatofibrosarcoma, also known as dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) is a rare, slow-growing, well-differentiated primary fibrosarcoma of the skin, associated with increased production of platelet-derived growth factor-beta. It presents as a protuberant nodule within a firm, indurated plaque that can ulcerate. They are locally aggressive tumors with high recurrence rates. Treatment is wide excision and Mohs microscopic surgery. Imatinib is used for unresectable, metastatic, and recurrent tumors. The given image below shows a DFSP near the umbilicus.

Option B: Marjolin's ulcer is a painless, slow-growing, locally malignant, well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma that occurs in a chronic scar (burns scar, scar of venous ulcer). It presents as an indurated, non-tender ulcer with raised and everted edges with scarring in the surrounding area with marked fibrosis. The ulcer can spread to the lymph nodes when it reaches the normal skin. A wedge biopsy and MRI of the region involved confirm the diagnosis.
Management is by wide excision, for larger ulcers, amputation is done. The given image below shows a marjolin's ulcer of the leg.

Option D: Naevus is a common benign neoplasm caused due to mutations in the components of the RAS signaling pathway. It has various types, such as congenital naevus, blue naevus, Spitz naevus, halo naevus, and dysplastic naevus. The given image below shows a patient with multiple dysplastic nevi.

Melanoma is a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction. Though it represents only 4% of skin cancers, it accounts for 80% of deaths (high mortality rate).
It presents as a pigmented lesion that has enlarged, ulcerated, or bled.
Histopathological confirmation is the gold standard in the diagnosis of melanoma. It is divided into four main types: nodular melanoma (NM), superficial spreading melanoma (SSM), lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM), and acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM).
The treatment consists of wide local excision of the tumor and follow-up to detect any local recurrence around the scar and excluding nodal spread.

Note: Pseudo-Hutchison’s sign is a reflection of the pigmentation of the nail bed and nail matrix through the transparent nail folds.

a nodule that has been rapidly enlarging.

Both Breslow and Clark’s system is used for melanoma staging.
Breslow thickness is the depth of invasion measured from the granular layer of the epidermis to the base of the lesion. As the thickness of the melanoma increases, the prognosis worsens. Clark's is based on the layer of skin to which melanoma has invaded.
Breslow thickness has largely supplanted Clark's as it is a more accurate method of predicting prognosis.

The best prognostic factor in primary stage 1 melanoma (T1N0) is the tumor thickness or depth of the melanoma.
The presence of lymph node metastases is the single most important prognostic index for melanoma in general. But in Stage 1 melanoma, as there is no lymph node involvement, the depth of the melanoma is the best prognostic factor.
Other major prognostic factors, in order of impact on survival, include:
Presence of lymph node metastases
Ulceratio
Age

Solution to Question 23:
The order of prognosis for types of melanoma from better to worse is:
Lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) and acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) > superficial spreading melanoma (SSM) > nodular melanoma (NM)
The LMM and ALM both have long horizontal phases. As a result of this, there will be more time to detect them before they enter the vertical phase of growth. Thus LMM and ALM have a better prognosis than other subtypes.
The SSM has an intermediate prognosis, as the horizontal phase is rapidly followed by the vertical phase.
The NM has the worst prognosis, as there is no horizontal phase and it starts with a vertical growth phase. This leads to a greater average tumor thickness.

Hemangioma is a benign tumor caused by the abnormal growth of blood vessels. Types of hemangioma are capillary hemangioma (most common), juvenile/ strawberry hemangioma, cavernous hemangioma and pyogenic hemangioma.

Solution to Question 28:
Extramammary Paget's disease arises most frequently on the vulva. Other sites include the perineum, scrotum, perianal skin, and penis.
Extramammary Paget's disease (EMPD) can be primary or secondary.
Primary EMPD is more common and occurs in the absence of an underlying malignancy, thought to arise from intraepidermal parts of apocrine glands or from pluripotent cells from the epidermis.
Secondary EMPD arises from an underlying adnexal carcinoma or internal malignancy due to the epidermotropic spread of malignant cells from the underlying tumor.
Visceral malignancies associated with EMPD are carcinomas of the colon, rectum, bladder, urethra, cervix, and prostate. The patient presents with well-defined, moist, erythematous scaly plaques and severe pruritis. Lichenification and excoriations may also be seen.
Diagnosis is confirmed by punch, wedge, or excisional skin biopsy. A systemic workup should also be done to identify any underlying malignancy and they include colonoscopy, cystoscopy, colposcopy, and pelvic examination with pap smear in females.
Treatment:
Mohs microscopic surgery with 5 cm margin clearance
Radiotherapy
Topical 5-fluorouracil and imiquimod
Chemotherapy
Photodynamic therapy

The given scenario and presence of large vacuolated cells with mucin (Paget's cells) points to a diagnosis of extramammary Paget's disease. It is a form of intraepidermal adenocarcinoma.
Extramammary Paget's disease usually presents in the sixth to eighth decades of life. It may occur in the genital or perianal regions, or in cutaneous sites rich in apocrine glands such as the
axilla. Approximately 25% of the cases are associated with an underlying in situ or invasive neoplasm.
It most commonly presents with pruritus. The clinical appearance is similar to mammary Paget's Disease. Scattered areas of erosion and white scale can give rise to a “strawberries and cream” appearance. The invasion of the lymphatic system by the tumor gives rise to underpants-pattern erythema.
Surgical excision forms the basis of treatment.
